reviewText:
SUMMARY
Obsidian's Fallout: New Vegas is the last good Fallout game. It features everything good out of Fallout 3, features superior writing, and a generally better feel.

REVIEW
Fallout: New Vegas. Otherwise known as Fallout 3 that should have been".

Imagine Fallout 3 but with more meat. A lot more meat. I mean a mega-ton more meat. That's New Vegas. Basically
hoursPlayed: more story
voteText: better pacing
helpfulPercent: more interesting side quests
votesHelpful: more weapons
votesTotal: more interesting perks
votesFunny: the re-introduction of traits
commentsCount: interesting factions
column16: and interesting locations.\n\nNew Vegas manages to revive the feel of the classic Fallout games by including fun
column17: interesting characters
column18: grimy locales
column19: and choice with consequences. In the first few moments of the game
column20: you are given a number of choices that can influence how the rest of the introduction will play out. For example
column21: the starting town of Goodsprings is facing a problem with a gang known locally as the Powder Gangers - merciless thugs that use a lot of dynamite. You essentially have four choices: help Goodsprings
column22: help the Powder Gangers
column23: help no one
column24: or kill everyone. But it's not so straight forwards
column25: as there are subtle ways to complete the quest without following the most obvious - being to complete all the objectives. I'll leave the rest for you to find!\n\nThe visuals are improved only slightly from the previous installment
column26: but they get the job done and can be easily improved using an ENB filter. The basic gameplay mechanics are the same
column27: but there are some improvements here and there. The game shines with its writing
column28: proving that Fallout isn't about the guns and loot as much as the story and characters.\n\nNew Vegas is known for its large modding community
column29: and it has more files on Nexus Mods than Fallout 3. They range from small tweaks
column30: as in the popular "New Vegas Anti Crash
column31:
or as expansive as Project Nevada - which changes the fundamental gameplay of New Vegas, adds new weapons and armors that are well balanced, adds neat visual effects, overhauls the stealth mechanic, and more. If you are a returning player of New Vegas and haven't played in a while but are still looking for an interesting and immersive experience, I recommend these following mods:

- Project Nevada
- Enhanced Camera Mod: makes third person animations visable in first person (check the ini!)
- Nevada Skies: adds new weather affects, like rain and sandstorms. Works well with Interior Lighting Overhaul which changes the mood of all rooms in New Vegas to be more realistic.
- All of Vegas Uncut, especially Freeside Open and the Strip Open.
- Enemy AI - Tactics - NPC Healing: just generally makes the AI better and more interesting, plus optional AI healing.
- EVE: New effects for explosives and energy weapons
- MTUI and oHUD: MTUI is just a more PC friendly hud set up, with small fonts, more room in menus, etc. oHUD is a suite that includes imersive HUD options, (HUD disappears after a moment) adjustable HUD options, and extra HUD options (hardcore needs, clock, etc.)
- WMX: Adds a bunch of new, balanced weapon mods.
- Classic Dialogue Options: Doesn't tell you when you have a skill check in dialogue. For immersion, etc.
- Enhanced Blood Textures: Generally better and meatier looking blood.
- Pipboy 2500 mod: it's not a big, ugly Pipboy, neither a gay readius
- Flashlight NVSE: adds a host of different flashlights, for when Nevada Skies nights are scaring you away
- Fallout 4 Quickloot: The only good thing to come out of Fallout 4.

CONCLUSION
Where Fallout 4 failed miserablely to capture the intangible essence of Fallout, the folks over at Obsidian managed to craft a fantastic Fallout game that is worthy of being placed alongside the classics.

Fallout NV is one of my favorite games. It has a great atmosphere,quests,and locations. The modding for the game is top. I reccomend this for anyone that liked Fallout 3(and all who dont need dragons or orcs and elves in a rpg xD)

The Fallout series takes place after a nuclear war and the U.S. is desecrated, a shell of its former glory. Humanity emerges from the tragedy as selfish and power-hungry as ever. Despite the bombardment of numerous nukes, the city of Vegas managed to survive the war mostly untouched. In the aftermath, a group of people formed touting the values of the old governmental system and called themselves the New California Republic, or NCR. Thanks to the Hoover Dam, the NCR and citizens of New Vegas have access to clean water and power, something most areas lack. At odds with the NCR is the Legion, a dictatorship lead by a man who renamed himself Caesar. Based on the Roman methodology of conquering other civilizations, the Legion absorbs nearby tribes and enslaves a portion of their population. The NCR and Caesar's Legion butt heads over control of the area, and tensions are high.

Deception, cannibalism, space travel and drug use are all themes, really crazy sometimes :)

reviewText:
Never would one imagine that one would find so much to do in such a grand role-playing world. If I were to define New Vegas in a brief sentence, that would be my definitive statement. The extent to which this game has changed me whenever I replay it is incalculable. So much so that it is a difficult task to enumerate its many virtues. I will try to stick to vital values.

Firstly, this is a game that adapts itself to several gameplay tastes. Whether one wishes to play it casually, attentive to storytelling elements and lore progression, or whether one would rather feel the potential for post-apocalyptic survival that it presents, New Vegas is there to provide it. Explore the numerous side-quests or discover how influential and emblematic each of the four main-quest personalities of the game (Yes-Man, Caesar, Mr. House, General Oliver and his entourage) can be. There is never a shortage of in-game mythos prone to in-depth unearthing by the player should they be interested enough. On the other hand, the game is so self-sufficient and self-explanatory as to not demand any background knowledge should the player choose to ignore Falloutian lore. And all that wholeness executed in perplexing 18 months by the careful minds at Obsidian.

New Vegas steps into the chaotic territories of mechanic bugginess from the infamous Gamebryo/Havok combination, but manages to keep major nuisances at bay. I have never experienced a single game-breaking bug or glitch, only the minor and even amusing stuff. And although the mechanics was already dated when it was released (late 2010), New Vegas feels like a fresh journey with its simple but timely additions - among them I can bring up the Companion Wheel, shooting downrange, and the addition of a hotkey to switch between ammo types; not to mention the precise crafting system and the hardcore gameplay option.

Characters are as close to perfection as you can get with an RPG. Brilliant voice-acting, immense sense of uniqueness in each of the relevant characters, and an actually solid story given to each and every one of the player's companions. This is the good old Fallout 2 companion system that we are discussing here, only improved. A set of quests intertwined with the main conflicts shall give the player valuable support for the entirety of the game's mythos, as almost every companion has a history with the Mojave to be scrutinised. The emotions enticed by such quests can vary greatly, and only serve to reiterate Obsidian's sharpness in delivering an authentic, almost flawless rendering of branching storyline in an electronic RPG. And these are just side-quests. I am not even going to discuss the merits of the game's intricate main storyline, as I leave it up to anybody thinking of buying this title and playing it for their first time.

Willing to abandon your real-world anxieties for valuable moments of embedding yourself with an immersive post-apocalyptic experience? Investigate or intimidate, persuade or kill, hide or bring mayhem about, survive or secure your niche, craft or buy from merchants. New Vegas gives you all said options to prosper and unveil its stories. The Mojave awaits, and it will reveal a thousand mysteries as long as one is willing to travel extensively across its horrifying deserts. Those points and several others are some of the reasons why this is one of the most impressive videogaming enterprises I have ever witnessed.

FALLOUT NEW VEGAS PUTS AAA TITLES TO SHAME!Incredible game for ludicrously low price.

If you are going to mod new vegas after playing for a while, I strongly recommend the following mods from Nexus Community

Project NevadaMakes the game even more interesting than it already is. You can have optional FPS Shooter elements with Project nevada. Dynamic Crosshair, Bullet-time, Peripheral vision etc, fully customizable you can enable or disable them at any time. Also to mention Cybernetic implants which give the player extra perks.

True leaning, by XilandoEssential if you are going to Install Project Nevada, or Stealth. A very simple mod which allows you to peek from corners. Thats about it.

NMC Texture PackThe game is a little old, but NMCTP revitilazes the game giving more realistic and detailed textures. Will consume extra space on your HD but worth it definetely.

Bottle that WaterIt's odd that Obsidian devs missed such feature, by default you don't have the possibility to refill water from lakes, pumps or fountains. But thanks to the modding community now you can.

The mods I recommend going on and on, there are definetely more essential mods but I wrote the most important.

reviewText:
Honestly, having played Fallout 3, Fallout NV with all the DLCs and recently Fallout 4..

NV really stands out as the game that captures the spirit of the Fallout universe the best.
It can be a tough game to get into if you're not used to what Fallout is about.

In short, you can do anything you want in no real particular order, the NV universe is big and diverse, and allows for plenty of hours of amazing gaming. You'll have some emotional moments (especially in the DLC..), some WTFmoments, and you'll have loads of laughs.

For me, this is a must have for every gamer. Just buy it :)

reviewText:
New Vegas is a faithful sequel to Fallout 2: New Reno. Much like its predecessor, the game features a desert, gangsters, casinos, guns, surprisingly good role-playing. The game takes place in the Mojave Wasteland � a pretty much lifeless, HUGE and twice as many locations as F03.  It's a bleak world without much hope and the choice is between bad and worse.
New Vegas does have a few technical issues. Overall, the game is best played not as a sandbox but as a more traditional RPG where you explore the main quest, which, depending on your choices, will send you to a variety of locations. New Vegas is a huge game. I can probably write another 6 pages examining New Vegas's various aspects but i'd rather play more. This game is only improved upon with the INSANELY TALENTED modding community with some quest mods even better than the ones Obsidian has written themselves dont forget all the armour, weapons, the re-texture's and mods that increase the difficulty of the Mojave.

Without a doubt a MUST OWN! even without mods and any DLC its just so great it would be a crime to not pick this up worth any amount of money.

reviewText:
I usually don't do lengthy reviews, but, hey, it's Fallout.
Pros:
- Great story
- Hundreds of quests
- Can run smoothly on probably any computer
- A lot of choices
- Mods
- DLC
- Dozens of different play styles
- Easy and challenging
- Dozens of weapons and locations that I haven't even been to yet.
- S.P.E.C.I.A.L
Cons:
- Can be buggy
- Crashes
- Sometimes frustrating
- After playing it multiple times, Goodsprings is repetitive

Some things you might care about:

Question: I like (genre) games, and not western games like New Vegas
Response: Chances are, Fallout: New Vegas has some of that genre. It's not horror, but sometimes creepy. Also, if you don't like western games, it doesn't really matter because New Vegas has it all.

Question: Do I have to side with the good side?
Response: No, and there really isn't one good side". You can side with the NCR
hoursPlayed:
or Yes Man.

Question: How should I approach this game?
Response: In my opinion
voteText: approach it how you'd like
helpfulPercent:
at least in the first play through.

Conclusion:
Should you get this game?

Absolutely. $10 for a game this great is a steal. I have 125+ hours so far on this game and I haven't played every quest yet. Words cannot express of how good a game this is."

reviewText:
Uh...
I don't know what to write here..
So i'm just going to give you the recipe for making waffles.


Ingredients:
2 eggs
2 cups of all-purpose flour
1 3/4 cups of milk
1/2 cup of vegetable oil
1 tablespoon of white sugar
4 teaspoons of baking powder
1/4 teaspoon of salt
1/2 teaspoon of vanilla extract



Steps:
1.Preheat waffle iron. Beat eggs in large bowl with hand beater until fluffy. Beat in flour, milk, vegetable oil, sugar, baking powder, salt and vanilla, just until smooth.

2.Spray preheated waffle iron with non-stick cooking spray. Pour mix onto hot waffle iron. Cook until golden brown. Serve hot.


12/10 - Would make waffles again.

reviewText:
Day One: Got shot in the face by a dude in a business suit. Woke up in a doctor's house, nicked all his stuff and ran. Got into a bit of a tiff with some locals, but I remained level-headed and gunned them all down brutally.
Day Two: Travelled to a town with a giant dinosaur statue, which needed help with some ghouls in the nearby ruins. Went to ruins, sniped down ghouls, stole their loot. At that point, I was attacked by an invisible demon, I panicked and shot grenades everywhere like a spaz. Repaired a rocket ship, loaded it with some more ghouls, shot it into the sun.
Day Three: Made it to New Vegas. Got shot at by some Elvis impersonators, removed their skulls in revenge. Bribed my way into the casinos, at which point my game crashed.
Go figure.

reviewText: This is one of the best games I have ever played. The reason ... the freedom. Sure you could say it’s for the graphics (not), or the amazing story line, or even the gameplay. No, the freedom the game offers you is amazing. You start of a guy/or gal, woken up from a shot to the head that should have killed you. Although some information was given about the person you choose to play as, I would have liked to seen more from the game. From the start you are given various options as to how you want yourself to be represented. As a hero, or an anarchist. Aside from the freedom you also get lovable characters and their factions, the decisions you make, and locations you venture off to that you   WILL remember. Graphic wise, the game isn't strong. The animations aren’t either. But you know what who cares, oh you do? MODS!!! The modding community of this game is huge, however it has  gotten smaller but sure as hell isn’t dead. The community is still alive and still pumping those sweet, juicy, hot mods you want. The mods include many things like : texture packs, weapons, or weapon mods; quest, npc's, and a whole lot more. Don’t like the mods the community has to offer? Make your own! The game does have a creation kit,yes it is confusing, but with a little practice you’ll be making mods better than a lot of the stuff on the sites. Sure the game isn’t perfect but you can make as good or as horrible as you like depending on what you do in the game or what you do to the actual game.

reviewText:
Ok, now that I'm waiting for Fallout 4 to come out, I guess I'm going to go back and visit the Mojave for a while.  The counter above the block where I'm writing this says I've played for 490.9 hours.  I might be willing to concede that such a thing is not necessarily healthy.

Nevertheless:  if you consider yourself a gamer, and you haven't played this, you need to snap it up and find out what you've missed.  Some may wail about crashes:  cry me a river.  Save periodically.

Yes, you may find some graphical oddities from time to time...but if you want richer stories, or more authentic post-apocalyptic atmosphere, you're probably going to have to wait until the real thing happens.  On the plus side, your wait might not be that long...so there's that.

There are an endless supply of mods out there as well, so even after you've played through, you can still revisit and find new things.  Don't like the color of the post-atomic sky?  There's a mod for that.  Want real firearm textures? They got 'em.  Want to own your own casino?  You can fix up the one in Primm.

If'n you don't, folks will be saying that 'Clint Eastwood' is the biggest yella-belly in the...whoops...wrong review.

What are you still reading this for?  Step to!  And tell Victor I said Howdy!""

reviewText:
There are lots of people who say that Fallout 3 is better than Fallout: New Vegas because Fallout 3 has better dialogue, or more interesting characters, or makes you care more about the world than New Vegas does.

Those people are lying.

Let's start with the obvious one: The world. In Fallout 3, you basically have a choice of being a good guy or being a ♥♥♥♥♥♥-bag, but no matter what, you are railroaded into following the main quest line, which is to grow up in the vault, leave to chase after your father, join up with the Brotherhood of Steel, and fulfill your parents' dream of a wasteland filled with life. The only difference between a good" and "evil" main quest completion is which of two options you pick at the very end
date: either putting a modified FEV strain into the water supply to kill off "unfit humans
recommended: becoming a eugenicist in the process, or not doing that. That's it. A Do you want to be evil? Y/N" dialogue box at the very end of the main quest is NOT GOOD DESIGN. Even worse
hoursPlayed: picking one choice or the other doesn't actually change anything after you complete the main quest.\n\nIn New Vegas
voteText: by contrast
helpfulPercent: you have four different ways to finish the main quest line
votesHelpful: and you're locked into picking one when you're still a few quests away from the climactic ending. Once you've firmly sided with one faction
votesTotal: the others  will shun you
votesFunny: and even attack you if you're particularly mean to them. The fate of the Mojave wasteland is real and dynamic
commentsCount: and you get to shape it to your will far more than you can the Capitol wasteland.\n\nAnd that's not even mentioning the fact that it takes a solid ten minutes in Vault 101 before you're let out into the world
column16: while you only need about sixty seconds of listening to Michael Hogan before you can start roaming in New Vegas. The tutorial in NV is more organic than F3
column17:
and completely optional.


What about the mechanics? Well
column18: F:NV has everything F3 does
column19: PLUS a fully-flushed crafting system (Fallout 3 let you make 10 marginally useful items from blueprints; New Vegas has dozens
column20: maybe hundreds
column21: of craftable items) that includes campfire remedies
column22: reconstruction and recalibration of bullets
column23: improvised ammo
column24: natural poisons
column25: and lots more; the ability to AIM DOWN YOUR SIGHTS (I didn't remember how much I valued that until I picked up Fallout 3 again); a higher level cap and more - and more specialized - perks (lots of Fallout 3's were just "Add 5 points to this attribute and 5 to that one!" Boring.); the need to choose two handicaps at the start of the game to make each playthrough pose its own challenges; faction disguises; a hardcore mode; decreased effectiveness of V.A.T.S. to make the choice of whether to use it or not meaningful (in Fallout 3 you could just spam Jet with Grim Reaper and mow down tons of foes without thinking; NV makes you play more tactically); and lots of other things I've mostly forgot about. From a mechanics perspective
column26: then
column27:
Fallout: New Vegas does beat Fallout 3.


What about characterization? Lots of people have said that they just didn't care about the characters in Fallout: New Vegas the way they did the characters in Fallout 3. I can only conclude they didn't get exposed to any video game characters before playing Fallout 3
column28: because New Vegas' characters are definitely more flushed out. Companions are the best example of this: In Fallout 3
column29: your companions have the personality of two lines in a speech bubble stapled to a cardboard cutout with a crayon smiley-face drawn on. There are no real differences between the companions: They simply run around
column30: shoot whatever weapon you give them
column31: and have a few generic lines of dialogue. In New Vegas
column32: however
column33: each character starts out holding a part of their personality back from you - you know
column34: like people in real life. They have personal motivations
column35: and will leave you if you do something they don't like (for example
column36: retired NCR ranger Boone will leave if you start hurting NCR people
column37: Cass will leave if you have very low Karma
column38: etc.). If you do things they like while they're travelling with you (for example
column39: if you have Chuck Bartow- I mean
column40: Arcade Gannon in your party when you direct HELIOS One's power to Freeside and Westside)
column41: you will eventually trigger more dialogue options where they tell you more about their past - because they trust you - and
column43: you can trigger a quest that has them confront their past
column45: and what their future holds. You

column49:
and I love it.


I'm not going to bother getting into nitpicky things like weapons
column53:
so of course there's an improvement in the variety of items. That's to be expected.


In short

reviewText:
Note: I've spent hundreds of hours on this game excluding its DLC on the console versions.

There are so many good things that can be said about this game, from gameplay to side quests to how the S.P.E.C.I.A.L and skills work, but I can only say one thing that makes me prefer this game so much over Fallout 3.

I would have to say it is the constant references to Fallout 1 and 2, by exploring the wastes, talking to people, and even gathering items from those times, you can really see how Obsidian pays tribute to the games they helped create whilst under the name Black Isles. From the tales of a screaming Sargeant stationed at Navarro, to tales about The Master, and finally to the Chosen One blowing up an oil rig; it's obvious the wastelanders will never forget about the amazing tales of the Vault Dweller and the Chosen One. Neither will Bethesda, Obsidian, and most importantly, us, the players.

You will never get bored of this game, it's a masterpiece just like the games before it.
10/10

reviewText:
Uh
Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead

Ingredients:
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg
2 large eggs, at room temperature
1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature
1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed

Now to make it
1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.
2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.
3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.
4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed
5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.
6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

reviewText:
You were fooled. Tricked. Betrayed by the man. But you wake up from the grave with a mighty lust for revenge and nothing is going to stop you.

Thats how i felt when I first started playing New Vegas. I think it has one of the most amazing beginnings of any game, because you just feel that you have the get back at the man who shoots you in the opening cutscene. A lot of people have spoken in a negative way about how the game isn't open from the start, and while I partly agree with that, I don't think it matters that much becuse starting your journey towards the strip is just so engaging.

Like any other game from the fallout franshice the experience is what you make of it. If you just use the first gun you find, only follow the main storyline and don't talk to people and explore, you're probably not going to get that much out of the game, althoug it is certenly playabe that way.
To get the most out of this game, you have to immerse yourself in your character that you can basically make your own in most ways; from what faction you are going to side with, handling delicate situuations peacfully with you charm or going in guns blazing killing everything is sight, how you are going to look and act during dialouges.

The game is however full of bugs (and not just the giant insects trying to kill you). Some of it can be excused due to it being such a large world with so much to do, but it can be annoying at times when the game freezes, some character interactions being buggy and objects glitching out.

But most bugs can be fixed throug unofficial patches since fallout probably has one of the largest modding comunities. This also means you can add endless amounts of content to game already filled to the brim with it.

Fallout: New Vegas is a great addition to the already fantastic fallout series, fixing alot of the problems people had with Fallout 3, like like the iron sight. It aslo contains probably my favourite storyline in the series so far, with gambling, gangs and a big battle.

8/10

Feel free to check out my other reviews.

reviewText:
After the huge dissapointment that ruined the fallout franchise and decided that Fallout should be a fantasy first person action game with an ilusion of choice codnamed 'Fallou 3' we actually get a Fallout game. Ladies an gentlemen, welcome to Vegas. New Vegas.

Now I'll be comparing this masterpiece to both FO3 and FO4:
New Vegas is set much closer to the original Fallout games, on the west coast, where super mutants don't exist everywhere for shooting things reasons, there are no colapsed buildings to force you to go around or use console comadns( that annoyed me so much the only way I was traveling the DC ruins was using tcl).There are no enemies named 'raider', the 'raiders' are part of different gangs. There are FACTIONS, something thatwas missing in FO3, and they don't shoot at you for gameplay reasons. In case you haven't figured it out I'm talking about the Enclave, who even if you side with them still try to kill you just so you have something to shoot at that shoots back at you. Speaking of the Enclave WTF are they doing on the east coast in DC? I tought they blew upp at the oil rig back in FO2. You can still find remnants of the Enclave scattered across the Mojave, and they are well aware thet the Enclave blew up at the oil rig, one of them can be your companion. Companoins who won't hate you because you want to make money. Oh, and inn this game you aren't a concerned middle-aged white parent, or a 19 years-old daddy's boy, no, you are a... mailman. The Mailman. Who has more than 4 answers to a question. In FO4 you had 4 options:
1) Yes(I'll help you)
2)A question that lead to the other options
3) Sarcastic( make a bad joke that will make the player feel embarased they chise it and help him)
4) I don't care about you but my character and quest  marker does so I'll help you anyway kind of option that will make your companion hate you
In New Vegas you can talk your way out of most situations with a SKILL check, and not having to quicksave before you choose something in case you have 10+ Charisma but you still fail. Also this CHR checks are not color coded for people with low INT(see what I did there) who can't read numbers. Also in FO4 INT no longer affects your speech, because they could't record so many lines. Take this for example:
Fallout 4
When you meet Kellogg, no matter what you say( all options indicating that you are a middle-aged concerned white parent) your options are:
I'll kill you
I'll make you suffer
I'll make you pay
A bad joke about killing him again in hell or something like that
You can't convince him to leave, either by a speech check or by having low INT, You can't side with him, BUT you can shoot him, because this what FO4 is all about: shooting things and being a middle-agedg concerned white parent
In FNV
When you talk to the Legate you can tell him to f*ck off, you can convince him to fight you 1v1 with a karma check(karma no longer being in FO4)

OR

When you meet with Benny you can just kill him, have sex with and kill him in his sleep, let him escape and tell him to let you live etc.
Also New Vegas includes dark humor, not bad and embarasing jokes that only a middle-aged concerned white parent would say. In FNV you have no family, no friends, it's just you, the Mailman. And that makes you feel like an adult making your own choices that affect the game.

The 4 main factions are: Mr House, The NCR, the Legion and Yes Man's independent New Vegas. When you finish a faction's quest you don't get the same end mission( yeah,you have to face Lanius, but under different circumstaces) like you do in FO4. Also, some may disagree, but its better if the game doesn't allow to play after the main quest because if you sided with let's say the NCR, you've probably done all of their quests before the second battle for Hoover Dam. If you would still be ablle to play, there'd be no legion, no Mr House so it's better if the game ends with the main quest. Also this game includes gambliing, just like FO3 and FO4, but unlike FO3 and FO4 it's gambling with chips and money and all that, not your skills and dialog options.
There are also plenty of smaller factions such as the Great Khans, The BoS, who can either help or work against in the second battle for Hoover Dam.
Take this for example: Colonel Moore from the NCRasks you to(spoilers) deal with the BoS. You can initiate the self destruct sequence, just kill them of sign a truce between the NCR and the BoS. Each of these options will give you a diffferent end slide, and the Courier can decide if the choice was either good or bad. You can play as a saint or thedevil's right hans if you want, you don't have to be the Wasteland's hero. FO4 wants you play as a good guy, but it doesn't really let you help people. In FNV you can really help people if you want to, like helping people in Freeside kick their habbits, not making you build houses like a minecraft ♥♥♥♥♥♥ for 'settlers'  who are never happy. There are plenty of houses in Boston, you don't need more.

reviewText:
Well, where to start? Hmm, ok, the main story of New Vegas: VERRRRY well written! An almost perfect balance of difficulty, questlining, exploration and cast of colourful characters. An awesome 4 different endings for the final Hoover Dam battle, deciding the ultimate fate of the Mojave forever. Plenty of side and faction quests to keep you occupied for an easy 100+ for completionists.

The factions are very cool, with some very interesting backstories, e.g. how the NCR are the re-construction of the democratic world, or how the Legion are basing themselves on the success of Pre-War Rome. Definitely adds to the throwback of the Pre-War era.

Ok onto the DLC's:

Lonesome Road: Ok Lonesome Road has got to be my favourite DLC by far. The amazing and yet emotional story of the true destruction of human nature, The Divide. The hellish nightmare you'd think most of the Fallout world would truly be. With plenty of secret US Govt. bases and awesome prototype laser weapons including Red Rocket. A heartwarming and cold-blooded ending with the tale encrypted into ED-E, and an epic finale showdown in an OPERATIONAL Nuclear Missile Silo, with the option to change all Faction relations in the Mojave with the option to Nuke NCR or Legion... or BOTH! 10/10 would replay many times!

Old World Blues: This was an interesting DLC. Travelling to an old Pre-War Area51-esque science base called Big MT, having your Spine, Brain and Heart removed for robot parts, and then quest to overthrow the facility and track down your old brain in a very epic confrontation. Definitely will recommend this DLC to anyone. 10/10

Dead Money: Ok, so Dead Money. This DLC has a unique and interesting storyline, of a super luxurious casino opened on the day of the Great War bombings in 2077. Having never opened, and left sealed in a cloud of toxic dust, it has been haunted by the ghosts and holograms left to rot. I liked the story of the Greatest Heist of the Century. Howecer, the downside to this DLC is the unbelievable difficulty. It took me as a Lvl50 character, 9 hours and about 12 deaths later to beat it. Its a good DLC, but needs to be nerfed in Difficulty ALOT! 6/10

Honest Hearts: Honest Hearts was the kind of DLC made specifically for the more strategic and cartegoraphical advanced player. Not an easy terrain to navigate in the Utah badlands, but a very cool Native American-esque story with many tribes scared of Pre-War structures, living the old native way, under threat for warmonger tribe White Legs. And a heartwarming story to decide the fate to Fight or Run to save the Sorrows and Dead Horses. And a very confronting meet with The Burned Man himself.... 9/10

reviewText:
I remember waiting anxiously for Fallout: 3 to finally arrive. I had played and loved Fallout and Fallout 2. I had waited for  years, and could barely contain my excitement for a modern Fallout title to be released. I have no shame admitting that I enjoyed playing the game immensely. However, I always felt that it just had the Fallout name slapped onto a post-apocalyptic RPG, with a few Fallout-esque elements thrown in to loosely tie it to the previous titles. While the post-apocalyptic atmosphere of the DC ruins was incredible, It didn't follow in the intellectual footsteps of the previous games in the Fallout lineage, nor did it maintain the same feel.

When Fallout: New Vegas arrived, I was completely blown away. It exceeded my expectations in every way. The setting in the American Southwest maintained the atmosphere of the original titles.  The faction system allowed for alliances to be forged within the Mojave Wasteland, but like the real world, denied you the possibility of making everyone happy. While I believe there was a mistake in maintaining the clunky Karma system of FO:3, I felt your choices within the game were more morally grey, more reflective of the world wherein there are actions and consequences rather than an arbitrary definition of good and evil. The major NPCs have excellent dialog and some of the most compelling back stories in gaming. The base game is good in and of itself, but the DLC add dimensions that are unparalleled in any of the previous Fallout games and the modding community has produced many excellent add-ons which enhance the gameplay and appearance far beyond the vanilla offering.

I have devoted more hours to this game than any rational adult should. It is by far my favorite game of all time.

reviewText: This game is honestly the best modern Fallout title to this day. It fixes almost everything that Bethesda flopped with in the original (DT is better than DR, the locales are pretty believable, dialogue checks are guaranteed with proper skills), and it just feels like what Fallout should have been with the transition. There's no level scaling, so there are some locations that are probably a bit too difficult until you reach a certain level, and it doesn't feel like an empty land to explore. There's vegetation and people trying to go about and make the world seem as if it's trying to repair itself 200+ years after The Great War rather than the DREARY POST APOCALYPTIC WASTELAND THAT STILL SOMEHOW HAD FOOD IN GROCERY STORES. Good character writing, quirky but not too far out there, and factions are well done. Karma system still sucks but is essentially irrelevant.\n\nAlso, unlike FO3, there are actually 200+ endings in New Vegas. Just play this buggy mess instead of Fallout 3/4, because Bethesda needs to know that they suck at Fallout, and it's a shame that we might not see Obsidian take another jab at it. Remember to consent with Fisto.

reviewText:
Have you ever been a long-time fan of something, gotten really excited when you heard it was coming back, only to be massively disappointed with the result? Fallout 3 had this effect on many fans of the Fallout series, myself included. Thankfully Fallout: New Vegas was developed under Obsidian Entertainment, a smaller company known mainly for Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II. The project leader was Joshua Sawyer, the same person in charge of the original Fallout 3 that was cancelled after financial troubles with the developer’s parent company. Fallout: New Vegas serves as a “return to form” for the Fallout series, bring it back to its roots in exploring the ethics of a post-apocalyptic world, not exploring the world itself.

Returning to Western USA, New Vegas is set in the Mojave Wasteland, directly adapted from the real world Mojave desert. Being a western the art direction of the game has changed from Fallout 3 but it should look familiar. The horrible green tint has been replaced by a much more subtle (yet still a bit annoying) orange tint, Buildings a much more suited to the environment (with much more varied interiors) and a good portion of the game world is actual desert. Despite being set on a desert, the sheer amount of content in New Vegas is densely packed in a logically designed world that is easy to navigate without a map, thanks to cleverly located landmarks. Gone are the days of trying to distinguish between this pile and rubble and that pile of rubble. The Mojave also features a number of areas that are very dangerous to lower level players, while level scaling does exist, it only ensures that enemies aren’t just cannon fodder at later levels.

Moving from Fallout 3 to New Vegas won’t feel too different gameplay wise. While the two are very similar, New Vegas is improved in every way. Iron sights have been added to make first person shooting a viable tactic, VATS has been reworked to be less unfair for enemies, Guns skill no longer increases bullet damage, etc. Character creation has had a few smaller changes but the ways your point allocation works in the world has been greatly improved. Perks are only gained once per two levels making you still human by level 30. Traits make a welcome comeback from Fallout and Fallout 2 where you can choose a nice little perk but at the cost of something else. Fallout: New Vegas allows great flexibility in what kind of character you want to play as, and all character build are perfectly viable. Want to be a gunslinger who kills and instils fear in all who oppose him? Go Ahead. Want to be a pacifist? Using your words to solve issues? Sure, New Vegas allows you to. Being able to shape the game, rather than just play it, is what makes Fallout: New Vegas stand out among modern RPGs. It’s surprising how not many Role Playing Games actually let you Role Play. While at launch the game was buggy beyond being playable, the game has been shaped by developers post launch to be the most stable Gamebryo game in existence, not a hard title to achieve but a good one nonetheless.

You play as “The Courier” and while delivering a small package to the New Vegas Strip, you are ambushed and end up in a shallow grave. Miraculously you survive the encounter and begin your quest to retrieve the mysterious package. A common misconception with Act I of the story is that it's just a western tale of revenge. The reality is that the story is about the package you were meant to deliver and using it to determine the fate of the Mojave Wasteland and its inhabitants.

The two main factions, the New California Republic and Caesar’s Legion are battling for control of Hoover dam and the conflict between the two is apparent throughout the whole game, and by the time you finish Act I you should be near a decision on who you want to side with, or if you want to side with one of them at all. Unlike Fallout 3, New Vegas is not a simple tale of White Knights vs Evil Moustache twirling cartoon characters and many of the game’s decisions are morally ambiguous as opposed to black and white choices. Because the game predominantly features factions with unique motives, it makes sense to reintroduce the Faction Reputation System, as opposed to relying on a heavily flawed Karma System. Players can complete quests in a variety of different ways, and in favour of different people. Whether it be through distribution of electricity, or destroying the NCRs monorail; the variety of ways to play the game makes it unrivalled in terms of replayability.

Interacting with the seemingly infinite number of NPCs is a joy. Dialogue is excellently written and everyone has lots to say. The Skill checks the feature are well varied in the skills they use and expertly written to be believable. “Your predisposition towards anger suggests unresolved issues in your past” sounds like a credible thing someone trained in Medicine would say. While the number of voice actors is only a small improvement over Fallout 3, the quality of the voice acting is a massive improvement, characters personalities are greatly enhanced by the brilliant voice work done. Facial animation still leaves a lot to be desired but it’s still an improvement.

Because Obsidian Entertainment consists of many ex-Black Isle employees, including the series creator Tim Cain, New Vegas is very faithful to the canon established by the first two games. The game also plays a lot like a first person version of the old-school RPGs. A lot of NPC interaction is involved making the game more about interacting with the world than exploring it.

Fallout: New Vegas does well to capture the atmosphere of Fallout, a world rebuilding after a nuclear holocaust. Adding to this is the soundtrack, which is largely comprised of the atmospheric music from the first two games. While it’s disappointing that very little new score was composed for New Vegas, it’s still infinitely better than the action movie soundtrack of Fallout 3. Radio stations make a return and play music appropriate for the retro future setting. Though this time with radio hosts that actually make sense in the world of Fallout.

If you enjoy RPG experiences with deep lore, plenty of replayability then Fallout: New Vegas is for you. If you just want a simple minded shoot and loot then it may not be for you, but I still highly recommend it. It does a fantastic job of bringing Fallout back to being… Fallout.

I don't know what to write as a review for this game so instead here is a recepie on how to make a pancake, enjoy c;

Basic pancakes recipe
A delicious and easy pancake recipe that is fast to get on the table and better tasting than any convenience pre- packaged mix.

Serving Size:
8

Category:
Basic recipes, Breakfast, Budget, Cakes & Baking, Dessert, Easy recipes, Kids cooking, Kids food, Lunch box, Pancake recipes, Snacks

Prep Time:
5 mins

Cook Time:
10 mins

Ingredients:
1 cup (150g) self-raising flour
1 tbsp sugar
1 egg, lightly beaten
3/4 cup (180ml) milk
50g butter, melted
Method:
In a bowl mix flour and sugar.

Beat in the egg and then milk at little at a time until batter is smooth and lump-free.

In a hot pan or flat grill, brush butter over cooking surface and pour 1/4 cup measures for each pancake.

When large bubbles form on the surface, flip over and cook until lightly golden on the other side.

Enjoy!

reviewText:
I really can not recommend this game enough. Easily one of the best RPG's ever made thus far. I may get some hate for this, but in my opinion, Fallout New Vegas has out done Fallout 3 in nearly every regard. The story is pretty great. It can be slow at times, but when you make decisions, they feel like they actually matter. The setting is something many people used to praise Fallout 3 for, including myself, and it is no doubt one of the best game settings ever, but after several play throughs of New Vegas, I feel the Mojave has that extra bit of charm that the DC wasteland didnt have. Some disliked the Mojaves bright skie's and bright City for a post apocalyptic game, but for me it just felt very right. The writing for some of the Side Quests in this game, is truly phenominal, and I hope Obsidian gets another shot at a Fallout game once Fallout 4 is out. Overall Fallout New vegas, and the Fallout franchise as a whole is a master piece, with rich and interesting Lore, great characters, excellent gameplay, and HOURS of replayability. Expect 100+ hours per playthrough, and even then you'll still have not done everything. My playtime on steam for this is only about 128 hours as of 2/14/16, but when I used to play this on console, id say my time on it is around 600+.

**EDIT: Having now played Fallout 4 and its overly simplified rpg elements, i've come to appreciate this game even more than when i originally wrote this.


Here is a summed up list of the Pro's and Con's of Fallout: New Vegas



PRO's

-Amazing and vast, variety of weapons.

-Interesting and Fun characters.

-Extensive character customization.

-Great leveling system with awesome Perks.

-Excellent setting.

-Good story, and great variety of story paths and Choice's.

-V.A.T.S

-The Pip Boy 3 thousand, Enough said.

-DLC's add a good amount of content for your character to take back to the Mojave. The way the DLC story lines tie in with the main games narrative is ♥♥♥♥ing excellent, making this games DLC some of the best i've ever played.

-Very well optimized for the PC. Runs better on my fairly average computer than it did on my Xbox 360.



CON'S


-Occasional crashes, not as big a deal as people make it out to be. You should be fine unless your trying to run this on an Etch A Sketch or a Potato.

-Sometime's a glitch will interfere with a quest or you might get stuck in a ledge. This is also Very occasional and not a real problem at all.



If you dont already own Fallout New Vegas, why are you still reading this, go buy it. NOW!.

10/10, Would herd Wind Brahmin Again.

reviewText:
This review. Like my Fallout 3 review will be long.

For my Fallout 3 review go here: http://steamcommunity.com/id/chaoticmayhem/recommended/22300

Fallout New Vegas still stands as one of the greatest games ever to be enjoyed not only as a Fallout fan but an RPG fan as a whole.

The game brings together combined elements from Fallout 1, Fallout 2, and Fallout 3. While adding a few things of it's own here and there to make the game even more exciting. To top it off this game presents Hardcore mode, which basically turns Fallout New Vegas into an (almost) realstic game.

Combat- Combat has seriously improved since Fallout 3. The combat in this game instead of a straight forward shooting up your enemies with VATS with a few grenades here and a rocket launcher here, and a lazer gun here and last aid of your companions or the other faction that is fighting your potential killer, you will have to rely mostly on 'special ammo' for example, if you are attacked by a deathclaw the only way to kill it or bring down it's 'defeneses' (the name will have a shield icon right next to it) is by using armor-piercing rounds.

Music- The music of this game is both combination of western and Vegas style. You will need music mods to make that list grow even larger. But in the end it doesn't really matter because both music pieces presented in Fallout 3 and Fallout New Vegas are great either way.

Quests- There is a barrage of quests, not only from the modding standpoint, but also DLC and the game overall. You will spend a lot more hours with these quests as the same amount of hours you do with Fallout 3, and the other Fallout titles

Companions- Companions are no longer Lydia's with guns" They are actually smarter and with the aid of the companion wheel it makes life SO MUCH easier when talking to your companion for him

reviewText: Fallout: New Vegas and Fallout 3 are some of the best games I have ever played, but to me; NV was just simply better than Fallout 3. Its all because of 2 very simple things, one being factions and the other being karma. You can be a phycotic killer, wiping out towns like Goodsprings and Novac and still get one of the NCR endings. You can be a prince of goodie-two-shoes and still get a Legion ending. You can ally the smaller factions with you even if the NCR or Legion tells you to wipe them off the map and get them to help you with the Hoover Damm battle. So yeah, you can steal eveything in the Wasteland and still get a good ending. The only faction I did not really like was the BoS (Brotherhood of Steel) because they only appear in one location, and you need DLC for them to be able to idolize you. Other than that Fallout New Vegas is an amazing game, and its better than Fallout 3 for the reasons I have given you. Thanks for reading!\n\n-Dario

reviewText:
Just thought I'd share an old preview of the game that I did when it was first showcased at PAX.  Fallout: New Vegas lived up to every anticipation, and is truly an excellent game worthy of the series.


______________________________________________________________

I just returned from my first PAX, where I managed to get a good look at the upcoming Fallout game: Fallout New Vegas.

The Bethesda booth had demos on the X-Box, only allowed you to play for a (theoretically) 15-minute interval, using a demo savepoint, and had lines at least 45 minutes long -- all of which gives you a very limited look into the game. But fortunately, I discovered that the Nvidia booth had a Fallout 3 demo for the PC, often with no lines and a gameplay duration limited only by your conscience. As such, I was able to get in several hours of play in the new game.

That said, I avoided most anything that would spoil the plot for me, as well as avoided major areas like The Strip. Instead, I focused on learning what I could about changes to gameplay, and I'm writing to share those with you.

What I've learned:
(If you've been looking forward to this game, some of these things you will probably already know from other reviews and spoilers.)

Fallout New Vegas uses the same engine and basic gameplay as Fallout 3, but incorporates a lot of things from Fallout 1 & 2 that Fallout 3 dispensed of, and includes a lot of game tweaks previously only available in mods.

Visually, the game is beautiful. The green haze is gone, giving us a bright blue sky and a lush desert landscape which is heavy on oranges and browns.

Traits are back. Traits are special perks, available only at the beginning, which either modify the game a little or which give you a benefit at the cost of a drawback. You can pick two traits for your character. (One trait, Wild Wasteland, adds additional 'wacky' content and modifies existing content and special encounters" that makes connections to the bizarre encounters you could have in the first Fallout games.)

Skills have been mildly revamped. "Small Guns" and "Big Guns" are now just "Guns". Plus
date: they have added in the "Survival" skill. (More on it later.)\n\nA lot of the perks from the older games are apparently back. In addition
recommended: opposite-sex perks (like Black Widow) now have same-sex equivalents.\n\nFood items now give you health slowly over time rather than in a single lump sum. With sufficient Survival skill
hoursPlayed: you can activate any campfire you find and cook food (or otherwise combine foodstuffs) to create superior foodstuffs. For example
voteText: you can cook gecko meat to create a gecko steak which is much healthier.\n\nSimilar to the "recipes" for food
helpfulPercent: you have the ability to modify or break down your weapons with a sufficient level of Repair skill -- you can even break down scrap metal into lead. You can add silencers

reviewText: A great rpg with a steady pace throughout the game. If you want a new generation fallout game that better represents the originals then this is the game, it follows a greater focus on character development and how you interact with the world; appreciating the fact that not everyone cares about pure run and gunning (you can still do that but there is a high chance of death involved). It may be a sudden change from the atmosphere of Fallout 3 now that they have somewhat of a more civilised stable society and its rather reminiscent of the wild west styled games but that only serves to continue the atmospheric development. If you can embrace actual adventure and actually role play then you are in for a treat of post apocalyptic wild west vibe. All I can say is give it a shot and don't try to compare it to Fallout 3.\n

reviewText: A lot of people don't like this game as much as Fallout 3, but in my opinion I find New Vegas better than FO3. Like FO3, you explore a large wasteland and take on different quests, explore different locations, encounter different people/creatures/things trying to kill you, etc. I like New Vegas more because of its larger selection of weapons, cool DLC (My 2 favorites are Old World Blues and Lonesome Road) and a vibrant modding community that adds even more weapons, gear and the like. Also, there's a Hardcore mode where you really have to pay attention to your hunger, sleep and radiation levels, as well as not lug so much ammo around (ammo has weight in Hardcore mode).

reviewText: Fallout: New Vegas, is possibly one of the most successful video games published to the Steam Community. Not only becuase of its sense of real life war, conflict of nature, and real grasp of a post apocalyptic world, but also becuase it allows to feel yourself as you might in the real world. An example of such is how it allows you create your own character, with your own tastes in style, color, and even gender.  It also gives you the feeling of bonding with other NPC's as they as well have a design, much like one you would find in the real world itself. Another very popular and inspiring thing for this game, is its open world enviroment. You can do what you want, go where you want, take who's side you want, and say what you want. Along with a more then wide variety of armor, weaponry, and most anything else you can think of, to choose and select from. And if that isn't enough to satisfy your tastes, you also have the ability to install mods, to perk up the enviroment, change many differant aspects of the game, the people, places, and things you interact with, and even yourself. Though this is a spin-off from the Fallout games, 1 2 and 3, this world still allows you to imerge in a whole differant world that you would likely never find in any other game. And if you're the type who is up for a challenge, you can even use a feature, known as Hard Core Mode"

reviewText: Yet another phenomenal addition to the Fallout IP. Fallout: New Vegas touches on many of the original concepts and mechanics of its predecessor but also improved on them. The amount of content in New Vegas and its ability to immerse you into its lore is astounding. How you shape yourself in New Vegas is virtually limitless, almost every choice to be made has several alternate paths that affect your experience greatly. Leveling in New Vegas feels more rewarding and desired than most games, sculpting your skills and traits are perfectly done here. In combat your options are huge, ranging anything from fists to laser rifles to mini-nukes. With the addition of Steam Workshop, your options and the amount of content really do become limitless.\n\nFallout: New Vegas truly peers on top amongst the greatest in the genra. If you are a fan, you won't be disappointed. If you're new here but love immersive open-world RPG's and have an interested for post-apocalyptic scenarios, you're in for quite a ride. 94/100

reviewText: The current game in the Fallout Franchise, New Vegas awaits, to entertain, to corrupt, or just to provide you with those home comforts, like that 12gauge you just never get tired of pumpin'. Gun firing a bit crap? Go upgrade it at the Gun shop by trading all that crap you found lying around, for that shiny new recoil compensator for your 5.56mm Marksman Carbine!! This game is an excellent RPG/shooter hybrid. I personally love the V.A.T.S combat system, allowing you to momentarily step out of real time to select those body parts that you think will look better being severed from that body, you don't know why, but you just wanna see the guy's head explode ha ha ha! Hrm...who's that over there, hey! It's a companion, make friends, get them to carry all your stuff, on first name terms already? Great, Why not give them a gun and some ammo too and you can double team those mutated Wasteland horrors like they were the best days of your life! (well they were for me mmkay..)  Choose wisely on the course of action to take when encountering strangers, or just  generally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ off the army. Not sure about that creepy looking character you met in that strange bunker? Hrm...do his bidding? Or betray him, up to you! Run off with the loot or give it to the homeless people for street cred, the reputation is yours for the making as everyone you interact with has the potential to aid you, or slow you down (cos you spent waaay too much time zooming in on her ti- ♥♥♥♥..) After over 200 hours of playing this game, I'm lightyears away from getting bored of this Titan, I aint never growing up !!! 8/10. There's room for improvment..but that's what sequels are for, fool! Load up and get your kit, it's gonna be a long walk and your gonna need to get your game on out in the Wasteland..some of the critters out there just get real mad if you shoot them! Good luck! Oh..and try not to die!

reviewText: Frankly, I'm astounded by how good New Vegas is. It brought back the true Fallout feel, especially the clever and witty humor. On top of that, it completely overhauled everything that Fallout 3 had, producing mechanics that actually work rather well, a world that gives you incentive to explore and reward for doing it, a great deal of solid difficulty, much improved combat, and a TON more role-playing ability. The only problems are that the story is somewhat weak and it has a MASSIVE amount of technical issues. Still, this is what Fallout 3 should have been.

reviewText:
Really loving this sequel to Fallout 4™,they improved a lot by adding different types of ammo,even craftable ones,more skills,skill checks in dialogue,they even added a survival mode where you actually need to drink,eat and sleep! Really surprised that Bethesda being the masters of innovation that they are,didn't think of that for Fallout 4™!

Conversations are more fleshed out,the characters are interesting,really loving the writing in this,which improved a lot,so huge props to the writing team over at Bethesda™!
They even added the ability to holster weapons and have them attached to your body which Fallout 4™ didn't have.

Overall very good game,improved a lot on Bethesda Game Studio™'s most ambitious game ever!

reviewText: This game has the potential to be so much more. Anyone who has ever visited Nexusmods and seen the library of content created as an addition to New Vegas, can attest to the potential of this game. Bethesda, off the heels of success with Fallout 3, in my opinion rushed New Vegas and released it before it was stable. Non-modded, Vanilla versions of New Vegas with and without DLC, are prone to random crashing. Now, even with that most annoying of pet peeves for all gamers, New Vegas is another post-apocalyptic, immersive sandbox, Taking place in the Mojave wasteland, and with the DLC content, surrounding areas. Instead of playing the intrepid vault dweller, you are a courier for the Mojave Express, who is gunned down. You must uncover the reason behind your attempted murder, find your stolen package, and unravel the mysteries within. The Brotherhood of Steel makes a brief appearance, but does not play the central role of law and order, the way they did in Fallout 3. Now we are introduced to the government and military of The New California Republic, as well as the despotic and sadistic masses known as Caesar's Legion. Fallout New Vegas is a game that must be played with all available DLC, for the full experience. Despite all the flaws, there are hotfixes, such as official game patches and player created Mods, to combat game crashing. If you enjoyed Fallout 3, you will love New Vegas.

reviewText:
Despite what Hideo Kojima would tell you, war never changes.

Fallout New Vegas returns the Fallout series to it's west coast roots, sort of. While little of the action actually takes place in The New California Republic, the state DOES play a heavy role in the title.

The player embarks on a quest of mythical proportions starting as a simple courier caught up as a pawn in the affiars of dicatators, emperors, and corrupt senators, and offers satisfaction to any who step into the wastes, in several ways.

One can endavor make the post apocalyptic, post divergent hell (as opposed to pre-apocalyptic, pre-divergent hell, or even conteporary hell) a slightly better place through feats of heroism. Alternatively one can take out their aggression at the powers that be by establishing new orders under nefarious leaders of varying degrees of nefariousaritynessnessism (sp?). Or one can simply say screw the rules

reviewText:
This rather divisive entry to the Fallout franchise is, for all real intents and purposes, the true Fallout 3.

If you can get past the general derp of the Gamebryo engine, you'll find one of the most beautifully realized gaming worlds of all time - all fleshed out with a myriad of well written and interesting characters.

Only real downsides are the general glitchiness of Gamebryo breaking immersion, and the rather easy/weak combat.

reviewText:
A game of limitless choices, possibilities, and complexity; something an RPG wants to be at its core. Fallout New Vegas is truly an 'epic' experiance, with a whole world of choices and options at the players fingertips, all of which is explorable and playable space. Want to be a space cowboy firing lazors and lever action rifles, sure. Want to be a swat trooper who bashes peoples knees in with a katana, you can easily do that. The game just has a lot of things to do.

These choices, compound into its ultimate game strength; the sheer amount of content there is. The game has a massive world, with easily 110+ quests, and probably even more unmarked quests. As well, the vast arsenal of weapons, the variety, and the balencing the game has in regards to these are phenoninal. Any playstyle is viable in this game, and it is an experiance where everyone can flourish. The game is perfecly paced as well, meaning that at no point are you this indestructable God of death, you are fragile, you are not the best, you are mortal. The game teaches you that very well, that you are human, nothing more. You live in this shattered world, dealing with your own human nature; whether it be the mortality, the drugs, sex, disease, or just plain stupidity.

But despite the games humanity, it falls into one major trap. That is, the game encourages metagaming at its finest. For instance, to get the best stuff/ending/quests, you need to know how/when to do things. This can be argued in the whole nature of the complex choice system as well, but because of the no turn back attitude of the game, it highly encourages veterans to play the game rather synthetically, rather than let it all flow together as it may. Yes, this does mean replayability, but its not as fun as a purely organic gaming experiance.

Despite the main criticisms of the game, and other factors I chose not to mention (for length restraints), the game is not bad. On the contrary, its quite good, very good. Why is it good? Because it emplifies its core concept excellently: Humanity, and what it means to be human. That focus in what its about, makes it a must own.

reviewText:
I recently played a game titled, Fallout: New Vegas, it was developed by Obsidian Studios, which many of the company’s members happen to be former members of Interplay Productions’ Black Isle Studios, the ones who brought you Fallout 1, Fallout 2, Fallout Tactics: Brotherhood of Steel, and Fallout: Brotherhood of Steel. The game was published by Bethesda Softworks, the Makers of Fallout 3, as well as one of my other favorite game series, The Elder Scrolls.

The game takes place in The Mojave Wasteland, which is the Post Apocalyptic version of the areas of Nevada, California, and Arizona. The game follows a The Courier who has a package delivery go wrong, as you find out at the very start of the game. This is one of the few games that I recommend watching the intro all the way through on, as the intro is very well done, in fact I enjoyed watching it my first playthrough, and then after I had played the game through several times, after which I noticed many different things that you would only notice after having played the game in depth.

The game is played in 1st/3rd person perspective, and the player interacts with the world and with items using a GUI called a Pipboy 3000, which can be upgraded to the Pimpboy 3 Billion (Which is a gold plated version of the Pipboy 3000.) after completing a certain quest. The game has a nicely done crafting system for creating items for the player to use/sell. You can make items from a few different hotspots, those would be, a fireplace or hot plate, a workbench as well as a repair bench.

This game unlike so many of its kind, actually has a nonlinear questline, which basically means you can chose who you would like to side with, as well as how you want to handle a situation in most cases.

The games main factions that you can side with during the main questline are Caesar’s Legion, Mr. House, the New California Republic (NCR), and for an independent New Vegas, you can side with a overly friendly and forthcoming robot named Yes Man.

Caesar’s Legion is led by no other than Caesar, aka Edward Sallow, Caesar co-founded his legion with a man known as Joshua Graham, whos name is not to be spoken within The Legion without punishment.

Mr. House or Robert House, founder of RobCo Industries, is a man who spent the latter years of his Pre-War life, planning for how to keep himself alive indefinitely, and protect the Vegas Strip from nuclear attacks.

The New California Republic is a fairly large democratic federation that is the absolute enemy of Caesar’s Legion.

The music choices in Fallout: New Vegas are fantastic, it perfectly fits in with the early 1900’s feel of the game and while a few may disagree the music itself is very good, with selections of the greats of the 1940s and 1950s with genres including classical and jazz. I feel like this revived a great period of time for music, so that new generations could enjoy it for themselves. This game is amazing and I would recommend it as a must play for gamers everywhere.

reviewText:
This is an amazing addition to the series, highly underrated. Has to be one of the best RPGs to date.

I highly recommend getting the Ultimate Edition to enjoy the brilliant DLCs, the game is much more complete with them.

Game-play is as amazing as ever, pretty much following the same game-play as Fallout 3 with a few improvements here and there. Strangely they decided to add an iron-sights mode when shooting, which would be fine, but seeing as this game doesn’t have the best graphics, it can sometimes feel like your aiming down a brick. This can be easily corrected by disabling it and going back to Fallout 3’s zoom, however.

All the guns feel great, all with a specific purpose and good against certain enemies, there is a great deal more strategy to the gun-play than with Fallout 3, with many more available stats, weapon mods and weapons which are useful in particular situations.

This game also introduces hard-core mode, where the game is set to the hardest difficulty (very hard) and forces you to eat, sleep and drink on a regular basis in order to survive. This mode tends to start extremely hard, with endless treks searching for water or supplies and provides a hefty challenge for experienced players, but once you’ve played this game to death, you’ll have enough supplies to not really have to worry about impending starvation any longer.

I could go into much more detail on game-play but many of my points would also apply to Fallout 3, which if you haven’t played, I recommend doing so before getting this.

As far as visuals and soundtrack go they are beyond exquisite, with a great mix of a western style Mojave theme and the classic 1950s twist that was evident in earlier games.

The story is excellent, following your life after being shot in the head. The game has over 62,000 lines of dialogue, holding the Guinness World Record for the most dialogue ever produced for a video game. It also has has some of the best written characters I’ve ever seen in gaming, most of them appearing the DLCs.

The actually story, well, that’s up to you. Do what you want; don’t do what you
don’t want to do. This is the definition of strong story-telling in a truly free game world.

Where the game has many of its problems is in mechanics. Perhaps it was rushed out, thanks to Bethesda only giving Obsidian 18 months to make the game. Very small aspects of the game do sometimes feel unfinished, or the remnants of an idea that was originally in the game are left lying around. There can also be a number of pesky bugs, most of which can be fixed by a few easily installed community mods.

What truly should sell you on this game is the endless supply of amazing mods on the Nexus. These mods with the game and DLCs combined will give you endless hours of fun.

reviewText: Set some 62,000 years after the events depicted in The Elder Scrolls series, this sequel welcomes you into a barren wasteland populated by ghouls, raiders, deathclaws and Benny. As a vengeful, brain-damaged delivery boy with VAC ban-worthy marksmanship skills you get to explore the vast and empty Nevada desert, laying waste to anything and everything that comes your way. You may pledge allegiance to the NCR and protect the helpless population, join the Legion and righteously cleanse the desert in the name of Caesar, assist numerous other petty factions or just wander the wastes alone like the worthless sack of ♥♥♥♥ that you are. If you aren't poor, you can also stop by The Strip - the heart of New Vegas, complete with suspiciously underpopulated casinos, arrogant gamblers and cheap hookers. If you've got the balls, you can also visit the one and only Mr. House at his own private casino, the Lucky 38, to learn more about that main storyline quest you completely forgot about. Before you begin your journey, head over to NexusMods and install as many nude mods as possible. Otherwise, you can play without mods (and without bouncing breasts) and enjoy the Vanilla gameplay along with the severely low intelligence that runs in your family.\n\nProfligate-tested, Caesar-approved; 10/10.

reviewText: Fallout: New Vegas is Obsidian Entertainment's take on the Fallout franchise using Fallout 3's engine, character building system, and assets, but the similarities of the two games pretty much end there. Saying Fallout 3 is bad" just because I happen to like New Vegas more would be too harsh. It's still a great game in its own right
recommended: New Vegas wouldn't even be greenlit if Fallout 3 weren't a commercial success

reviewText:
Perhaps its greatest strength is the fact that everybody can play it differently. Rigidly follow the main storyline – or wander off and ignore it entirely. Try and be as moral as possible – or kill and rob the first merchant you come across. It's a tailor-made gaming experience where everything can be done at your own pace and in your own way – no wonder it resonates with so many people.

Fallout: New Vegas, the latest addition to the FRANCHISE, exemplifies all these great qualities in the series' best outing to date.

The action this time takes place on the US west coast – the setting for the first two Fallout games – a decision which has granted Obsidian much greater scope for variety in landscaping and colour than the washed-out Washington DC of Fallout 3.

Being further away from the game's titular nuclear fallout, there's blue skies, singing birds and more signs of civilisation – a marked tonal shift from the unremittingly bleak scenery seen previously.

Aside from the familiar burnt-out cities and trailer parks, the centrepiece of this new setting is the New Vegas strip – a wonderfully distorted and dark version of its real-life counterpart. Vomiting drunks, voluptuous ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and a selection of fully playable CASINOS(better max out your Luck rating first) make it every bit as vivid and memorable as the decaying US capital of the last game.

In terms of the story, there's next to no foreshadowing this time around – players are expected to be familiar with the Fallout universe – and the main narrative follows your attempts to unravel the events leading up to your near-death, which prefigures the game.

Fallout: New Vegas
I've been asked a few times whether it's 'better' than Fallout 3's central plot and to be honest it's hard to say. It's a looser strand to follow, meaning side-questing fits in much more easily, though the blank nature of your character means it's hard to care too much about what happened to you – especially when there's so much fun to be found elsewhere.

reviewText:
I bought the GOTY version of Fallout: New Vegas during the last Christmas sale and it was the first foray into the Fallout world for me. I had played none of the previous games and was not willing to fork out the money to buy Fallout 4, a game that was released just prior to the sale and thus was still at full price. I wanted to see why people like the Fallout universe so much and since New Vegas was the most recent entry into the franchise after Fallout 4 and was quite cheap, I decided to buy it. Needless to say, I have no regrets. New Vegas is one of the best games I've ever played and it's easy to substantiate that claim.

To get started on the good points of the game, New Vegas is a very rich, albeit not in a monetary sense. The characters, story, and the atmosphere are breathtaking. The quests were really well-done and I didn't feel bored while completing the main and side quests, although the side quests were the ones that really stood out. Most of the game's content comes from side quests and it was really rare for any of those quests to feel mundane or lacklustre in any way. I constantly looked out for quest givers so I could complete the side quests they provided, and it felt fulfilling to complete them. Almost every location in the Mojave has a quest or more tied to it and it was great exploring the Mojave while doing the task that has been set before you. NPCs are numerous and you're sure to have memorable interactions with many a character in the Mojave, whether it ranges from doing stuff for them or popping a cherry in their forehead. Moreover, the choices you make will have an immediate and sometimes far-reaching impact on the world around you. Although you do get to decide the fate of the entire Mojave Wasteland during the main questline, your actions in side quests also affect the individual communities and organizations operating within the world, which also extends to having an impact on the main questline. The role-playing element is certainly very present in this game, and coupled with the amout of freedom presented to the player, it does make for an awesome experience. You have plenty of freedom to do whatever you want and be whoever you want to be. The game doesn't rush you or push you to do or complete quests; you can take your own sweet time by exploring and doing whatever you fancy in the Mojave. If you so wish, you can be a homicidal maniac and murder everyone in sight (and risk breaking quests in the process), or you can be the stereotypical western hero-type that engages in more benevolent activities. Your actions carry weight and it feels really good to know that you're shaping the Mojave in one way or another. In addition, New Vegas has a great modding community. Although the modding scene has slowed down over the years, there's so much good content available on the Nexus for download. I have 130+ mods installed and it has really enriched my experience of playing New Vegas. New weapons, gameplay overhauls, minor tweaks, new world spaces, more quests, etc can all be added if you manage your mods properly. You can even make the aged New Vegas look more aesthetic through the use of hi-res texture mods and lighting mods like ENBs although you have to be prepared to suffer performance losses, the magnitude of which depends on the power of your rig.

However, as it is with any other game out there, New Vegas does suffer from some flaws, some of which are pretty blatant. The devs had a very short development cycle for this game and some of the cracks really show. For instance, this game is pretty buggy and it runs on a very dated engine, the same one that Fallout 3 used waayyyy back in 2007. Compared to other games released around its time, New Vegas looks and plays quite badly. Animations are rather clunky and combat is not as smooth as I would like it to be, being pretty awkward and not quite responsive (Graphics and animation mods can somewhat mitigate this problem). Most of the time, I just found myself using VATS instead of aiming down sights due to hit detection issues and not wanting to deal with the whole unresponsiveness of gunplay. (VATS is awesome by the way) Crashes can occur quite frequently although downloading some mods can patch that issue. Also, locations are rather disappointing. New Vegas, which is supposed to be a bright, bustling hub in the center of the Mojave feels really empty and small, being made up of several main buildings. Casinos are dark and lifeless, and towns are quite small and lifeless. Yes, some mods can add onto those locations, but there is only so much a mod can alter. However, I must say that this doesn't detract much from the exploration and roaming experience.

To conclude, New Vegas is a fantastic game and I'm sure if Obsidian Entertainment were granted a longer time to develop this game, it would have turned out to be a greater masterpiece. Much work has been put into this game and we can see it in the role-playing, story, and character elements, and I see myself putting many more hours into this game. Overall, 9/10.
