reviewText: Fallout New Vegas is a very nice video game. From the story to the gameplay, it has eaten the past 100 hours of my life and I'm  very pleased to waste my time. From the art style to the music to the characters, it all just fits in so well. You could say that it's no different from Fallout 3 but unlike Fallout 3, this is a much brighter and much more difficult and polished up experience with only a few flaws within the game. The DLC is fantastic, offering lots of new content and areas to explore.\nHowever, there is the problem that it's a Bethesda game. Why is that a problem? Because it's buggy. You have to be careful with the game. If you can get over the annoying save bug (where you can't load your save, requiring you to start the game from the start in order to be able to load your oldest save), to some quest breaking bugs that require you to cheat in the console (I had this occur for me once, but still). The other problem is that the battle with Caesar is very very badly executed. But, that doesn't stop the game itself from being good. If you're looking for a very fun and enjoyable experience, I highly recommend you try it out. And the game itself isn't that expensive with all it's DLC anyway.

reviewText:
Ah, Fallout. My first true RPG, and one true love. Full disclosure, I prefer 3 to NV, but it's almost solely because of the radio personalities; Mr. New Vegas is just kind of...blah. Luckily, there's an all-music station, and the in-game sound track is pretty damn good, too.
So, hey, the actual game. For starters, super-fun story. I've always been a sucker for games that have you caught between large warring factions. New Vegas has three of them. Not two. ♥♥♥♥en three. AND, you can say to hell with all of them and throw in with the faction of Me, Baby, taking the riches of New Vegas for yourself. But whatever choices you make, they're all apparent during the final battle, which somehow manages to put Liberty Prime's curb-stomping rampage to shame.
The world is beautiful and makes me wish I had a better graphics card. The vaults in particular are very well-written. I still get a feeling of dread whenever I crawl through Vault 34, and Vault 22 is supremely fun with fire-based weapons. The world is solidified by the fact that, unlike in F3, there are a number of large, well-established settlements, with whom you can gain or lose reputation as you and your shooting sprees see fit. The terrain itself is varried, from sprawling dessert to rocky cavern to lush forest to snow-sprinkled mountain, all within about a day's run of each other.
Mechanics are glitchy but good as always. Love the condensation of Small Guns and Big Guns into just Guns, and the addition of Survival. I actually wrote my own physical copy of The Wasteland Survival Guide with all crafting recipes in it, just so I could better manage my inventory and decide what crap I could sell safely. I can't mod weapons to save my life, but based on the public achievement stats, I think I'm the only one with this issue. Doesn't bug me much, as there are enough unique weapons in-game to make moding almost pointless. I am, however, a huge fan of the new ammo types; armor-piercing rounds making it so much easier to kill higher-level enemies, and coin shot gives you something to do with all that worthless Legion money you're going to collect.
Buy this game, Ultimate Edition. Everyone talks up Lonesome Road, and while enjoyable (partly because it gives you access to the best companion in the game), it's one of the slowest points in the game - and filled with Deahclaws. Old World Blues is hilarious and gives you invaluable resources, Honest Hearts is beautiful in its simplicity, and Dead Money...well, Sierra Madre Martinis make Tin Cans worth something, and there's some good loot towards the end that does help your midgame. God damn, just writing this review makes me want to play again!

reviewText:
The Fallout series is one of the most acclaimed that has also a retro-futuristic touch that charms you when you see it for first time until you finish the game. New Vegas is no stranger to it's predecesors.

The player visits the city of New Vegas and it's Mojave desert that are just ruined by the radioactivity and the different factions that are in war. You, most known as the Courier, were hired to deliver an unknown package from the Mojave to the New Vegas Strip but you were intercepted, shot in the head, and left for dead by an also unknown man who steals it.
Afterwards, you are found and healed by a local doctor and then, your story begins. No complains on the writting department from me.

Being an Open World Action Role playing game gave Bethesda give the gamers so many things to do in the map: from following the main story, or just not and complete side quests; or from being an explorer of the wasteland to wander just in populated places. This game gives you freedom to choose what do you want to do in it and how do you want to develop your     story and character (as you have speech,lockpicking and multiple skills to upgrade by playing). This game even lets you choose how you want to end it as you choose your side in the faction crisis (NCR,Caesar's Legion, Mr House... or none)shown through all of the story. This is what keeps the player so connected to the game: the freedom of playing as you want.

The gameplay is  similar from Fallout 3: the Pipboy is back with all it's previous options modified a bit to fit in this game (radio included, lol), the Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System or V.A.T.S for the specific aiming of a limb and the real time effects of it (brilliant), the karma and your reputation (good or bad, your choice), companions, weapons modding and the adding of the Gambling (cheating is included) are the most unique things of the series and of course, it's signature. Even the new players can blend in without any problem.

Fallout: New Vegas is one hell of a game and will not steal minutes from your life because you will enjoy every second of it.
You won't regret the experience.

reviewText:
A fitting love-letter of a bygone era known only as the '50s, it reminds me of a dusty ballroom recording, with its crackles and pops, genuine improvisational finesse, and its propensity for dryness. It seamlessly blends diverse modes of visual art, ranging from retro-futurism to Art Deco to modernist sensibilities into its quirky and idiosyncratic world.

You, the Courier, wander the vast expanse collectively known as the 'Mojave Wasteland', a post-apocalyptic, divergent vision of the United States in 2281.

On a quest to seek revenge against a mystery man who left you in an unmarked ditch to die, you are inadvertently thrown into a quagmire between three major factions: the 'New California Republic', 'Caesar's Legion', and with the enigmatic 'Mr. House'.

The main story revolves solely on these three factions, which I'll get into in relative detail. (Spoilers below).

The 'New California Republic' touts itself as a last bastion of a democratic federation, structuring its government and its system of laws after pre-War United States sworn to egalitarian ideals. This ideology was handled rather poorly by bureaucrats and serve as an annoying hindrance to civic order. (They are now dealing with a conglomerate of loosely connected but independent city-states.) Problems arise regarding but not limited to: laissez-faire capitalism, populism, rampant corruption, extensive senatorial infighting, and most recently, aggressive expansion.

Edward Sallow was a former member of the Followers and the NCR. Here is a man who took charge of his life, as a true anarchist like himself would. He familiarized himself with the 'Commentarii', Julius Caesar's firsthand account on the Gallic Wars and emulated his character, even taking on his title. He quickly established himself as a man to be reckoned with, resorting to shockingly barbaric ways to make his point, and established the monolithic 'Legion'.

One might think Caesar's Legion would serve as a direct dichotomy to the NCR, but they're very analogous if you think about it: both are nationalistic (strictly in the traditional sense), militaristic, imperialistic, and arguably totalitarian. The Legion takes it one step further and obliterates the identity of every group it conquers"

reviewText:
This was the first of the Fallout Series that I've played and I am thoroughly impressed. The creators and successors of Fallout truly love their creation and put so much passion into their games and related items of interests. Only finishing FO:NV, I realise that I have only touched like 5% of the whole story. It made me curious and so I read the timeline of events in the whole Fallout universe and pleased myself with the reading of the whole story. I really enjoyed that as well!

(From a first-time player of Fallout) FO:NV has great FPS gameplay including the VATS feature. The leveling, skill, S.P.E.C.I.A.L, perk and reputation system is vast and astonishing. I enjoyed starting new characters with high strength and luck and yolo it out in the Wasteland. The mass amounts of items, armor, weapons, ammo and drinks you can find is another aspect that'll make me enjoy and not get bored. Storyline is very non-linear and links up few quests so you don't have to got through too much trouble. The A.I is nicely designed for the era of the gaming industry when FO:NV was in. Companions are cool and there are many options to do with the companion (fight, stay, disband or just have a nice chat). Overall I just think FO:NV as an incredibly badass game.

The main reason I played FO:NV was because of the massive hype for Fallout 4 that provoked me to try out the Fallout Series. I know now that I will definitely buy Fallout 4, when I have the money ofc. I am proud of Bethesda, Obsidian and the original creators Interplay.

10/10

I write poetry in my Brotherhood of Steel armor. Lasers are my ink. My enemies are my paper.

reviewText:
Personal Rating: Not a bad game - I expected more
Classic Rating: ★★★☆☆

New Vegas doesn't add too much to what we saw in Fallout 3, in my opinion: there are companions, enhanced crafting (which is pretty useless anyway), maybe more weapons and mods but it's the same old game - I can't tell one true change in game play or UI.

Main story falls short in comparison to FO3: NV it's mostly made of side quests - some of which very interesting, I have to admit - but all the Courier's story starts and ends in a flutter (not going to spoil).

● I loved FO3 dark setting, I liked New Vegas.
● I loved FO3 story, I liked New Vegas.
● I had some crashes in FO3, I had many more in New Vegas.
● I don't remember any particular bug in FO3, I found a lot in New Vegas - from mid game to end I had to open the wiki almost every time I played.
● I had to fast travel very often in NV because of silly quest while I spent more time actually playing in FO3.
● Factions implementation is not good in New Vegas, in my opinion: if you don't pay attention to what armor you wear, your playthrough can get f****d up.

As you can see, there's a lot of things I didn't like, BUT I cannot say New Vegas is a bad game; I can just tell to whoever is still doubtful about choosing Fallout 3 or New Vegas, go with the former, you won't be disappointed.

Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead

Ingredients:
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg
2 large eggs, at room temperature
1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature
1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed

Now to make it
1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.
2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.
3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.
4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed
5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.
6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

reviewText: There are two main groups of the Fallout fanbase as of 2011: people who played all the Fallout games and the much larger amount of people who only really played Fallout 3. I'm part of the first group. Leaving aside the fact that said group is the most toxic fanbase on the Internet, suffice to say that I think Fallout 2 was a big improvement over the first (awful opening area aside).\n\nFallout 3-gen fans tend to dislike New Vegas. But to people like me, Fallout: New Vegas is what I've been waiting for. It's designed by many of the people who made Fallout 2, specifically New Reno. The shortcomings I felt with Fallout 3--the lack of region/NPC-specific endings, the quest solutions not really having much of an effect on the game or world, the dialogue/writing of the NPCs, etc--have all been fixed here. The VATS targeting system is no longer invincible and targeting is redone to use FPS mechanics (where you aim = where you shoot). It'd be hard to go back to Fallout 3 from this, & I liked F3!

Now the stranger started talking, made it plain to folks around

The morning passed so quickly, it was time for them to meet

About to meet his death

There was forty feet between them when they stopped to make their play
And the swiftness of the Ranger is still talked about today

Big iron on his hip

It was over in a moment and the folks had gathered 'round
There before them lay the body of the outlaw on the ground
Oh, he might have gone on living but he made one fatal slip
When he tried to match the Ranger with the big iron on his hip
Big iron on his hip

Big iron, big iron
When he tried to match the Ranger
With the big iron on his hip
Big iron on his hip

reviewText:
Fallout New Vegas. The Fifth official installment in the brilliant Fallout series is wholly welcome.
Carrying on faithfully the looks and feel of the much loved franchise it's a brilliant addition and definitely elicits a huge amount of enjoyment.

The game depicts the adventures of 'the Courier', a man shot and left for dead in a grave yard in the town of Goodsprings. His quest was to deliver some sort of message... But it was stolen.  Venturing through the game you meet a wide variety of people and groups (including fan favorites such as the Brotherhood of Steel) and on your quest to recover the message you become involved in things much more important than you could ever have expected. The entirely new location allowed the Game Devs to include various new creatures and factions, allowing for interaction with strange new peoples.

The visuals of the game are slightly different to it's predecessor Fallout 3, the altered, now orange-y colour scheme is a bit alien to the normal colour pallete however is not too disappointing. An issue with the landscape that I had, is the fact that it doesn't look enough like it's 'just' after an apocalypse. The environment seems a bit too lively, but in fact, it may have looked a bit too repetitive if it carried on looking like Fallout 3 (I'm excited to see how Fallout 4 will look with its rumored Nuclear Winter environment.)

There are not many alterations to the gameplay as opposed to the last Fallout game - a style of gameplay which i have come to love with a passion. Fans of the series will be happy to return to using familiar mechanics such as V.A.T.S. which newcomers will quickly get used to.

Basically, the game is pretty damn good! The new environment and story line, as well as glorious DLCs (like Old Time Blues) make it a must have in any gamer's collection.

80/100

reviewText: Fallout: New Vegas may seem like an expansion for Fallout 3 than a stand alone game, but that is only at first glance. Fallout: New Vegas takes the focus of the Fallout franchise back to the west coast and does so in a very good way. The story isn't exactly amazing, however it lends itself to letting you create your own backstory, and making your own decisions. There really isn't too much to hold you back from doing what ever you want? The base game alone has hundreds of hours of contnent in it, and has a huge amount of replay value, from four different major endings and dozens of smaller end pieces. That being said it is not without a few flaws: namely the glitichs and instability. It manages to be worse than its predecesor in that regard, as well as numerous bugs; some hilarious, some that can ruin a run through. The only other real complaint I have is that you CANNOT continue the game after you beat the ending, which is a shame. Still there is more than enough to do in New Vegas, and with all of its DLC this is a must have for any Fallout fan, as well as anyone who likes RPGs.

reviewText: Fallout: New Vegas may seem like an expansion for Fallout 3 than a stand alone game, but that is only at first glance. Fallout: New Vegas takes the focus of the Fallout franchise back to the west coast and does so in a very good way. The story isn't exactly amazing, however it lends itself to letting you create your own backstory, and making your own decisions. There really isn't too much to hold you back from doing what ever you want? The base game alone has hundreds of hours of contnent in it, and has a huge amount of replay value, from four different major endings and dozens of smaller end pieces. That being said it is not without a few flaws: namely the glitichs and instability. It manages to be worse than its predecesor in that regard, as well as numerous bugs; some hilarious, some that can ruin a run through. The only other real complaint I have is that you CANNOT continue the game after you beat the ending, which is a shame. Still there is more than enough to do in New Vegas, and with all of its DLC this is a must have for any Fallout fan, as well as anyone who likes RPGs.

reviewText:
Easily one of the best RPGs out there. The engine is a bit outdated, but still makes a great Job in being fun. Specially if you mod the ♥♥♥♥ outta it.

Skyrim may have better graphics, and be more stable, but like most Elder Scrolls games, it lacks roleplaying. The TES saga is great for it's lore and dungeoncrawling. But in New Vegas you can REALLY play a different character. You can be a gay guy who's a smooth talker and doesn't need to fire a shot to get ♥♥♥♥ done, for example. The different ways to solve the quests, according to your skills is what makes the Fallout saga really great.

Of course, that's not the only thing this game has to offer. An awesome ambientation, the whole Fallout lore is so rich and unique. Since the smiling guy from the pipboy and all the 30s related humor, to a faction that tries to live by the rules of the Roman Empire, or the super mutants, and a lot more stuff. If Fallout has something that makes it different from other post apocaliyptic settings it's its humor and its uniqueness.

Comparing it to Fallout 3, it's better in pretty much every way. The decisions now aren't all be a good good person or be a evil evil man". There are more quests

reviewText: What an excellent game! I've played the entire Fallout franchise and in my opinion this game is what Fallout 3 should have been. Not to belittle the previous title in the series, in its own right it was a fun game, with an excellent storyline, but this game is truer to the original Fallout's quasi-Western-like feel. As with this games predecessors, you wander the apocalyptic wasteland, Immersive stories begin to emerge, with some pleasant story lines and character references to previous games in the series cropping up from time to time. In this game you will encounter a range of factions with whom you can choose to become friends or enemies. Many of the decisions you will make throughout the very open world/storyline will also transform your experience. One of the greatest aspects of this game being the fact that following the first playthrough you can make entirely different choices in your second playthrough (ie, appease a group you previously were enemies with on first playthrough or make entirely different decisions at key points in the game to unlock a totally different storyline) and enjoy an almost entirely new game experience - within certain limits. In some cases the storyline wont be as flexible as you may like and will limit how far your alternative version of events" can go.\n\nThere are other core features of the game that are equally important to mention - hidden storylines that you from time to time accidently stumble into in that second or third playthrough that will totally open up the game for you again and keep it fresh. There are numerous weapons
hoursPlayed: people to betray
voteText: people to ally
helpfulPercent: monsters to kill
votesHelpful: adventures to be had
votesTotal: decisions to make - and most importantly - the type of character you create as you play through the game. Do you wish to be hero and saviour of the weak? Or perhaps make sacrifices for "the greater good"? Are you super inteligent  and able to outwit those around you? Amazing with a rifle so that you can kill with a headshot before they get close? Perhaps you prefer to be a super strong brute that goes in close for the kill? Or are you the Rockafellar of the wastes - making a profit everywhere you go so that you can afford to buy rare and impressive weapons no one else has? The list of traits goes on
votesFunny:
and you can choose to specialise in some or be a jack of all trades (and master of none) - the flexibility is all yours. Do you seek revenge? Do you crave power and influence? Do you hate bandits or perhaps wish to be one? The choices are *nearly* endless.

The only thing I disliked about this game was not the game itself but the DLC. I only tried one or two of them and just could not enjoy them - even though they aim to expand some elements of the story line - I would consider giving these a wide berth unless you're particularly curious!

For those of you who love post apolocalyptic themed games

reviewText: Difficult to say everything that needs to be said, so I'll start with the easiest thing. This is my favorite game. I thought that Morrowind or Fallout 3 would be very tough to surpass, hell even Elder Scolls Oblivion was a pretty comprehensive experience, but no, Fallout: New Vegas is a masterpiece of gaming. The core game is great, but when you add the DLC it really becomes a massively worthwhile experience. Lots of moral choices, lots of options in how you can approach the combat, plenty of customization, single player even lets you recruit companions and equip them as need be. The settings are masterfully done, and have plenty of variation. Some stuff can plain creep you out, and some can make you want to just stand for a few minutes and take it in.  If you want a fulfilling experience get this game and play through it. There are enough endings and your actions carry over through even the DLC, so its easy to play 10 times through and have just as many final conclusions that are distinct from each other.

...Steam\steamapps\common allout new vegas
and find the following lines:

fDecalLifetime=10.0000
iMaxDecalsPerFrame=50

change the numbers to:

fDecalLifetime=720.0000
iMaxDecalsPerFrame=512

Bottom line: This is one of the best RPG of all time and can keep up with games like Morrowind and Skyrim!

reviewText:
War? War never changes. Neither does Fallout.

Between Fallout 3 and New Vegas not a whole lot had changed. Heck, usually a sequel adds significant technical improvements. Not New Vegas. New Vegas trades out the setting for a slightly different one, trades in its story for something that Bioware would be jealous of. And adds a few new weapons and options. Other than that, New Vegas and Fallout 3 are pretty much exactly alike. And that is not a bad thing.

I would have loved a more intuitive interface, or higher walkspeed, but I guess the developers held true to their creed of do not fix what isn't broke." They also didn't fix was was broken

reviewText:
If I had one word to describe this game I would choose Spectacular! A lot of people have criticized this game because it had a smaller map than Fallout 3, that is a terrible reason to talk badly about this game. Yes the map was smaller but the locations in the map were amazing. It was super fun to be able to explore all of the casinos. In quite a few of them you could even get your own room.

Pros:
One of the Best games of all time!
Beautiful vegas setting!
Lots of new weapons and combinations!
Several different endings that you can choose!
Only $10 retail and $2.50 during some sales!

Cons:
There aren't any unless the smaller map bothers you!

All in all this is a 10/10 game and for only $10 it is literally a steal. Seriously no other game on steam with a retail price of $10 is this good! If you haven't played it you are missing out!

reviewText:
A great FPS/RPG game.  It’s longer then most normal games with tons of replay ability and I’m still finding stuff I’ve never discovered.  NV also makes for a good follow up to Fallout 3, as they are build off the same engine and for the most part have very similar play style.  On top of that they reworked combat outside of VATS to make if feel more fluid with the ability to actually shoot down your sights even at low level over FO3.

Another improvement was to repairs for weapons were now you can fix a gun to max condition even with low repair  vs FO3 not letting you do that.  Lastly the change to companions and making them more useful over FO3 is great.  I liked having companions to help out and all of them have missions and stories their own that add even more to narrative of the world you play in.

New Vegas does come with a little baggage (Few bugs/CTD) but other then that, as long you have auto save on your ok.  The only thing that puts me off little on this game is it don't really have the apocalypse feel as much as FO3 does.  I'm ok with the more old western feel but I do miss the large destroyed city feel most of FO3 had.  Mods also can help add to your world, change whatever you want.  You choose how things turn out but as always, war… war never changes.
***9.5/10***

You can choose to join a legion of Trump supporters...I mean dangerous barbarians bent on wiping out the new civilization around New Vegas, the new military which has broken and divided leadership but means well for the people....or you could just screw them both over and go the independent path.

There are plenty of fun side quests and DLC that will give you hours of immersive entertainment.

reviewText:
Fallout: New Vegas is pretty much the post-apocalypse game I always wanted. You have a gigantic world to explore, countless number of side quests in addition to the already meaty and choice-based main quest The gameplay is satisfying and is is the perfect balance between RPG and action shooter. The game easily has over 150 hours of content with all the DLC. It is a proper RPG, letting you play how you want, be it a suave diplomat, a sneaky thief, or a thug with a very big hammer, and has multiple factions to side with for the end-game.

As someone who played the hell out of this on the Xbox, I got the game again on PC primarily for mods, and if anyone is considering re-buying for that reason, I whole heartedly say do it right now. Modding makes an already great game fantastic and utterly unique to you with thousands upon thousands of mods. Never a fan of any of the armour or weapons? There is probably a mod out there for you. Not a fan of the fast travel system? Get XRE cars and drive around the wasteland. Have Fallout 3 and want one huge game? Get Tale of Two Wastelands and combine them into one big game with the same character. Want the game to be less of an RPG and more of a shooter, with high damage numbers, sprinting and hotkeys for grenades and melee? There are indeed mods that do that. The possibilities are endless, and the main modding website for New Vegas is easy to use, letting you both manually install mods or have an app that does it for you if you aren't confident enough or unsure.  Pretty much any kind of mod you want, it's out there.

The main downside to a game of this scope if the stability, and while generally stable there are some very common bugs everyone will come across when playing the game. Of course, if you have played any other Bethesda-style RPG you will expect this anyway. I made a post on the forums which has the main ones you will need to make the game stable and mostly bug free:

http://steamcommunity.com/app/22380/discussions/0/522730700736948013/

I can not recommend this game highly enough. One of the best RPG's of the last generation. If you want to see how awesome this game looks, check out my screenshots.

reviewText: If you haven't been diagnosed with ADD prior to playing Fallout New Vegas, you definitely will be after playing it. There are so many places to explore, people to talk to, and things to do that it's difficult not to get distracted. But the game remains fun even when you happen to run off on some wild goose chase because the story flows so seamlessly. It never feels like you are on some irrelevant side mission. I love the stress-free freedom to do what you want, when you want to do it.\n\nThe game left me in awe as to how intricate virtual worlds like this can be experienced in such stunning detail--definitely worth spending my time and energy. Its biggest disappointment is the inability to continue character development and exploration once the main quest is finished. You are forced to load an old save...

reviewText: Fallout: New Vegas is easily and undeniably one of the single greatest games of all time (at least in my opinion). From the moment Ron Perlman mutters the simple opening line to the point in which you look back upon all that you have accomplished before your final decision at Hoover Dam, you experience a world filled with colorful landmarks and memorable people. On the surface, the game and its world seem crude, dirty, and vulgar but once that surface is cracked and you look inwards, you see an arrangement of mysteries and philosophies all waiting to be explored and experienced. Unfortunately, nothing can be perfect, every shining jewel is tarnished in some way or another- and in the case of New Vegas? The game is broken and unstable. You can not spend an hour in the game without experiencing the consequenses of an incredibly low budget and a development time of less than 2 years. Clipping issues, assets becoming distorted, quests not allowing you to progress, and so on. Not to mention the crashing. The game has some of the most insufferable crashes, often forcing you to sign out or restart your PC entirely. The final drawback of the game is its graphics. The game is ugly. It recieved no enhancement over Fallout 3. In fact, a noticeable percentage of assets and textures are borrowed directly from its predecessor. Of course all of these problems listed can be fixed with one simple method: mods. As one of the most heavily modded games of all time, its very difficult to run out of content, whether it be vanilla or added in at your discretion. Six years later and I still play this game regularly, and I'm hoping that Obsidian is given one more chance at the helm of the Fallout franchise

reviewText: I typically prefer to play simulation and strategy sandbox games because I can get countless hours of replayability versus games with a storyline as eventually the story ends. Reviews and trailers for Fallout 4 caught my attention, but I wasn't quite ready to dish out the money for a genre I've only started to dabble in recently. Fallout 3 and Fallout New Vegas caught my attention when it was discounted during this past Winter Sale, and I went with Fallout New Vegas because I was worried about Windows 10 and Fallout 3 not being optimized past Windows 7.  I am soon to be 30 hours in and there is someone with almost 4,000 hrs of gameplay out there, I do not regret my choice and it speaks to the opporunity to replay the game when I am done with my first playthrough.\n\nFallout New Vegas welcomed me in without the need to play the previous Fallout games, the storyline is captivating and well-planned thus far. The quests help me to explore an almost open world, exposing me to various creatures and gangs. I am not an expert and no where close to ending the game, but I like the fact that I can choose to replay the game differently by altering my choice of SPECIALS, skills, and choices that in turn affect how the game continues. I have restarted a few times while learning which SPECIALS and skills work best with the character build I am interested in. I finally have a better understanding of the setup and I find that the game provides a challenge without completely sinking and frustrating me as a new player to the genre and franchise. I imagined originally that I wouldn't like it because I don't typicaly play first person shooters but the whole aspect of combining elements of an RPG that I am dabbling with as of late with FPS has suddenly made me more fierce with a gun and explosives. I LOVE that I can cause damage but on the side of good. Some day, maybe I will walk on the darkside to see what else Fallout New Vegas has to offer in terms of quests, but until then I am shooting ghouls, creepy crawlers, and gang members in favor of those in need.

reviewText:
Fallout: New Vegas is a Post-Apocalyptic RPG that is a great change from common Fantasy-Themed RPGs

In the game you play as a courier about 200 years in the future where america has been turned into a Post-Apocalyptic radioactive wasteland by a war with China in 2077. Small towns dot the lands, while remnants of large cities are ridden with bloodthirsty junkies and criminals. While there is so much danger in the world, there is one gem that sticks out and attracts wealthier people from all around: New Vegas. A city protected by a mysterious overseer called Mr. House"

reviewText:
Whether or not you will like Fallout New Vegas will most likely depend on your personal preference. For example, it depends on whether you prefer the blade or guns. After playing Oblivion and Skyrim, I tried this game and was both pleased and turned off. The cool stuff:
I got a mod that imported Star Wars droids into the game, and they are awesome.
The costumes can make your character look awesome!
There is a jetpack mod......
http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/37140/?
The main city of New Vegas is pretty nice, and Freeside is fun to explore. The Liberty Loft is the house to get there.
http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/41822/?
In addition, it is easy to be a total bada** in the game, which is pretty fun.
The guns are also diverse and fun, the gunplay is solid. There are also throwable weapons (which Skyrim should have).
The soundtrack is good.
The uncool:
Oblivion and Skyrim spoiled me with beautiful worlds and exciting combat, so I expected a world ripe for exploration and screenshots. However, while it may be great for exploration, its sheer ugliness completely turned me off. On top of that, deadly monsters roam the bleak landscape and serve as bullet sponges, so I ended up being content staying in the City.
The NPCs seem fake and are not interesting (if that makes sense).
There are some annoying mechanics such as dehydration and radiation. It is fun sometimes and annoying as all heck other times.
There are great ENBs, but the game looks bad without them.

I now know that I much prefer Elder Scrolls over Fallout. Although Fallout has its perks, I will always rather invest my time in Oblivion and Skyrim's gorgeous worlds, spells, potions, sword combat, and quests. New Vegas' ugly and unrewarding world, unfortunately, dampened my excitement to do a serious playthrough.
But: Do not let this deter you. Try it out for yourself and see if you like the elements this game has that other games do not. Plus, check out the Nexus Mods. There are some pretty cool ones there!

reviewText:
I ♥ the post-apocalyptic vegas style, with the grimy feel of what once were grand buildings, casinos and neon lit streets overlooking a vast, scarce and dangerous wasteland, full of weird and sometimes wonderful things.

Customise and create how *you* want to play by altering perks, skills and attributes from the beginning and developing whilst levelling up. Shun or gain respect with different factions and choose a path of destiny with the bigger factions that play core roles in the main storyline.

The game is not really too difficult in normal mode but I enjoy playing this game in hardcore mode because it adds more realism to the gameplay, where carrying ammo is counted as weight, injuries take time to heal and ensuring to keep tabs on eating, drinking and sleeping enough.

The battle system uses VATS, a targetting system that is entertaining to use if  zoned in on an enemy and they happen to have the weirdest expression or pose at the time!

What really creates Fallout is the psychological dialogue of the characters encountered, giving clues to a history or a side-story in the background. Some of the characters are so quirky and memorable that it made me gain a thirst for knowledge about the fallout world.

I think you will ♥ this game if you enjoy a combination of RPG, FPS, exploration. Plus there is a lot of DLC to dig into along with completing the main story and exploring all of the wasteland.

Overall, this is one of my most loved games and I have to recommend it as one of the best games I have played, not just for the gameplay but simply for the character and role customisation that has been presented as an adventure. ♥

reviewText:
This game is great, but it also has many, MANY BUGS AND GLITCHES.
Pros:
- Good Story
- Many Quests, a lot more than Fallout 3
- Great Weapon Variety
-  Good and bad voice acting
- Many Followers
- References to the previous fallout games
- The best dlc's i have ever played
- Many different paths and factions to follow
- Great locations and level design
Cons:
- Bugs, frequent crashing, glitches
- Terrible Gunplay, you will probably rely on vats for many battles
- Bad Graphics, terrible for 2010
- Character Creation is lackluster, your character will most likely not look like you

I know i probably missed many things about this game, but this is what i came up with. I recommend this game to anybody who enjoys the fallout series and the dev and published Bethesda, then this is a must have game. If you enjoy western rpg's there is no better developer and publisher, however this is developed by Obsidion, and is made in a different sort of mood than Fallout 3. This game is bright and interesting. Fallout 3 can be interesting, but it is most often dark and gloomy. This is great game that anyone who enjoys rpg's should buy.

reviewText:
I have a good 250+ hours worth of play of Fallout:New Vegas, and I have to say that it is one of my favourite games, ever.

Bethesda have always been great with RPGs, but as my first experience of the Fallout franchise, this remains to be one of my favourites.

I have explored every possible element, looted every corpse, cabinet and dead Brahmin that I could find; there is SO much content, and with 3 DLCs, you have plenty to work with.

Some of the voice acting gets a little...groovy within dialogue, corpses fly to the ceiling with V.A.Ts shots, rescuing followers from behind boulders becomes a frequent chore, and if I have to listen to one more run of Johnny Guitar, I may scream...but a solid 10/10 overall from me.

In short; if you enjoyed Skyrim, give this a try.
For a lover of stories, I would say this still holds a lot of weight despite the new game now launched (just don't expect the graphics to be on-par.)

Guns rather than pew-pew magic.

reviewText: To review Fallout 3 or New Vegas is a difficult challenge. Not because their content is too hard but their expectations of what players want to enjoy are different. While seemingly similar in their mechanics, both games diverge in what players expect to enjoy in a Fallout" game.\n\nIf you have read my review of Fallout 3
date: then you know I consider New Vegas the more refined game. Traits
hoursPlayed: the faction systems
voteText: and the gray morality are important factors for what makes NV so great. However
helpfulPercent: it's the world-building that puts NV as one of the finest examples of open-world games.\n\nAs someone who has thought of open-world games as the death of narratives from the Ubisoft games to the missed opportunities of games like Risen
votesHelpful:
Obsidian has forever changed my opinion on their storytelling merits. NV doesn't tell the greatest story nor the smartest; it tells a world of tales of your interactions that shape the Mojave one grain of sand at a time.

Nuka Cola or Sunset Sarsaparilla?
Before I discuss the importance of NV's strongest suit
votesTotal: I do want to go over the improvements of NV. Many fans I think will consider liking F3 or NV to be something similar to the question
votesFunny: "Coke or Pepsi?"\n\nWhile both games are mechanically the same
commentsCount: there are noticeable differences. For example
column16: F:NV focuses more-so on the role-playing mechanics by making its perks more unique
column17: sometimes beneficial with consequences or adding a new level of challenge. F3 simply focuses on numbers and how to make them better. I found that by Lv 43 my character in NV still had room for growth whereas my F3 character was maxed out before LV 13.\n\nQuests in NV seem more shorter and to the point than F3. (Admittedly
column18: the travel time between each quest could be the reason for why they feel more brief in NV.) The Mojave is a more compacted
column19: content-rich area than D.C. which might be great to some (like me) and a negative to others. What NV makes up for instead is how questlines can feed into other quests seemlessly by the player's exploration and choices.\n\nEven when it comes to the FPS mechanics
column20: the iron-sights
column21: weapon mods and various ammo types for every gun make the barebones gunplay of F3 much more tolerable. (I find the repair/ammo-crafting benches too restricting on junk to ever warrant using them.) I hardly ever use VATS in F3 or NV unless I want to get headshots on Deathclaws.\n\nSpeaking of Deathclaws
column22: enemies in NV are not leveled to the player from the get-go. They are given a fixed level—and scaling later—which makes enemies more consistent in NV. This change does come at the cost of making the early part of NV more linear as you have to loop around the road to get to Vegas as your first major quest-goal. However
column23: like in Risen
column24: the game tells you this through the enemies' difficulty and there are quests/paths along a more linear beginning than F3.\n\nI personally prefer the grim-humor flavor of the post-post apocalypse of the Mojave over the post-apocalypse consistency of D.C. Your taste may vary
column25:
but I hope to explain why NV is the superior game.

It's All A Matter of Context
If you have played a Bethesda game before
column26: then you will more often notice a problem of its open-world design: The world always feels disjointed.\n\nQuests in Bethesda games have been focused on telling individual stories with little to no relation to one another. Tone-shifts
column27: relevance to the over-arching storyline
column28: and other narrative pitfalls suffer as a result. While some fans may enjoy this format
column29: the result is a world that feels more lifeless by their lack of context.\n\nFallout 3's main-questline is indicative of this problem. You go from exploring the Museum of Natural History to get a radar dish for a DJ
column30: to wandering to a city made of a shipwrecked vessel to learn about your father's science project
column31: then exploring a Vault with a murder-simulation program
column32: and then later stumbling upon a society of children.\n\nIn contrast
column33: NV begins with the town of Goodsprings caught up in the much larger conflict of the Legion encroaching upon the NCR claimed settlements of the Mojave. A gang of escaped convicts harass the people of Goodsprings who have stolen their explosives from the NCR mining outpost of Sloan to exert their power. (The result being that the explosions have lured out Deathclaws along the road of Sloan.) This gang has taken the town of Primm under their rule as they fight off the NCR stationed there
column34: and the gang's other settlement Nipton is under attack by the Legion.\n\nAs seen in this one example
column35: conflicts in New Vegas feed back into each other and expand upon the world it tells. This description of events is simply the background window-dressing to your actions as you can side with Goodsprings
column37: the NCR or the Legion. Your interactions stay within the story's guidelines of NV. Questlines also can link-back up with previous or new areas
column38: and the order of these quests can be stories you create for yourself (ex. Jacobtown and Black Mountain).\n\nWhat can also be seen in this one example is the careful attention to details. Why are Deathclaws roaming Sloan? Why are the NCR defending Primm/Goodsprings? Even in its environmental design
column39: there is a level of detail of the farming area of Goodspring to explain how a town can survive. Something that was utterly lacking in Fallout 3.\n\nThe reward from all of this attention to detail is that the world of NV feels more alive than it actually is because the world makes sense. Are there still tone-shifts or missing details? Yes
column40: especially with the cringe-worthy sexual tensions and swear-words. However
column41:
these moments are far less abundant and offer a dark sense of humor in a post-post apocalypse.

"I've Got Heartaches by the Number"
I would be lying if I said I thought NV is absolutely perfect.

While I praise the game's means of storytelling and of player-choices in the overall game there are some downsides that I think some people may enjoy. It took me years to be stubborn enough to play to Vegas because I was so used to F3's freeform exploration.

The narrative hook of NV is not one to keep you invested if you don't care to learn more about the conflicts around the Mojave. Even then
column42: the plot of the Courier is very sparse and not very personal. (On the otherhand
column43: the freeform nature of the Courier lets you make him/her be whoever you want.)\n\nThe rushed schedule of the game has had some impact on its development. F3's engine has really shown its age with how much NV has to restrict itself
column44: whether it be the barren New Vegas or the amounts of gated loading screens. Not only are aspects like this have to be rushed but even some interactions aren't coded in.\n\nFor example
column45: when trying to set a truce between the NCR and the Brotherhood of Steel
column46: if you had gotten rid of the previous Elder then the option for truce does not exist. It's not that the new one is arrogant and won't agree to it--the game is not programmed to understand that option. These type of instances are very
column48: very rare but they are a stain on the freeform nature of the game.\n\nOn the flipside
column49: it is really telling how much trust Obsidian has with its player when the game has one--and only one--unkillable NPC
column50: the Yes Man (aside from children and Victor in the early part of the game). Fallout 4 is littered with these unkillable NPCs while New Vegas offers multiple optional objectives/paths for almost every quest.\n\nIf Obsidian was given more time to flesh out the game and on a better engine
column51: then I think this game would be a perfect masterpiece. (In spite of its somewhat lackluster personal narrative.) Instead
column52: it's a masterpiece with a few smudges you have to accept.\n\nWith all these gripes being said... the day I stop counting that's the day my world will end."

reviewText:
Before I start the main portion of the review: I just want to clarify that I have spent hundreds of hours of Gameplay in the PS3 version of this game and I have played all the DLC in the PS3 version (You can verify, account name: DarkKingSpyder)
And that I'm playing the game with a few graphical mods and as such, this review is on Fallout New Vegas and it's content so I shall not touch upon the subject of visuals as I've modified my visuals.

Fallout New Vegas is the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Clear Sky of the two Bethesda Fallout games, when I say that, I'm mentioning the fact that people see Fallout New Vegas as inferior to 2008's Fallout 3. But this doesn't neccessarily mean that Fallout New Vegas is a bad game, far from it! Just that it's got less content than Fallout 3, but that doesn't mean that the game is short, far from it. But let me explain why I DON'T hold this opinion and find it superior to Fallout 3.

Storywise, this game is a humongous step away from 2008's not-so-open ended Fallout 3. Which had the same ''core'' ending, which was, someone finished Project Purity by sacrificing their lives(which we find out in Broken Steel that they were in a coma for just two weeks). This game can branch off and some quests can be ruined if you take a different method than normal. A minor spoiler: During two quests, named ''Heartache by the Number'' and ''Birds of a Feather'' I had to bring Cass to the Silver Rush in Freeside to collect evidence, when I had done so, I was forced into a giant gunbattle and then I had to end up killing everyone in Silver Rush, which then ended the quests ''Birds of a Feather'', and then later in the game, I get another quest named ''Tend to your own business'', which told me to kill the owners of the Silver Rush, the Van Graff Family. This is a HUGE issue with the game, if you take one branch fully knowing the consequences, then later encounter a quest that you wish to do to progress, you can't, as maybe, you might have done the same task in another quest. This is just one specific case. Which just might be a glitch with my game as I had never bothered with the Birds of a Feather quest on any of my other runs of the game, I just played until the part where they wanted me to deliver a package.

The 'branches' in the story really is just 4 branches, but within those four, each action changes a ''slide'' of the ending.
So, each run can be different AS LONG as you do something different in terms of your actions in a quest. The ''branching'' story paths has only been done right in this Bethesda game. Sure, The Walking Dead does branches nicely, but they change the story minorly rather than locking off CHUNKS of content that is related to working w/ another faction. This alone gives reason on why to replay with a different faction.  Or just reload an early save if you don't want to bother with going back to the Strip for the first time.

One of the additions to Fallout New Vegas that I loved was Hardcore Mode. Where food, water and sleep actually matter, rather than being means just to fill up your health and if you fast travelled, that could lead to you being more hungry, etc. etc. It's a welcome change to a game as other games don't incorperate this form of roleplaying. Also, if you're new to the  Bethesda Fallout games or newer Bethesda Elder Scrolls games (Oblivion onwards) and wish to do Hardcore mode, I recommend you to buy the ''Courier's Stash'' DLC, as it adds in an item named ''Vault 13 Canteen'' which is a nod to the Vault that the Main Character from Fallout 1 is from and also, is REALLY helpful if you're running through Hardcore.

The expansion packs in this game was done right BUT. BUT-THERE'S ALWAYS A BUT. There's Dead Money, OH, how I hate Dead Money, and I like difficulty, don't get me wrong but that crap in Dead Money was insane, ESPECIALLY in Hardcore. It's horrible, in terms of level design and how annoying it can be to start Dead Money for the first time and to realize that the only save that is BEFORE starting Dead Money is HOURS behind.

Honest Hearts is a real nice change of pace for Fallout, instead of having the normal Day and Night, there is a new weather effect which is rain and the landscape in Xion is BEAUTIFUL, I can't say how nice it is to be walking around on a mountain, then swim in a river, then calmly walk around in a cave. Everything is nice.

Old World Blues, a hated one by some members of the Community is only hated for the first few minutes, because too much dialogue at the start when you get abducted to start Old World Blues, if you like Sci-Fi, just play it, it's really nice to see a Sci-Fi based DLC as Mothership Zeta wasn't really Sci-Fi but more like what you'd expect in a 1950s/60s film which is nice due to the fact that Fallout seems to be eternally stuck in an era with stuff from the 50s/60s yet the bombs dropped in 2077.

Then, if you play the game's expansions in order, there is Lonesome Road, which is very climactic as it answers all the questions about Ulysses, a mysterious character hinted at in both the base game AND all the DLCs. And getting to him is difficult yet fun (I say difficult because I played the DLC when I was Level 4 when I got it, my main character got destroyed when my PS3's HDD got curropted and I had to replace)

Mechanically, it's the same as Fallout 3 but some things have been tweaked. And I also do recommend installing a Sprint Mod as sometimes, it's extremely slow at the start.

Definitely worth buying the Ultimate Edition or just the Base Game if you don't care much for extra areas.

EDIT: Since I've written this review, I feel I need to include this little part about Tale Of Two Wastelands in this review since I've been recently playing it and I'm in love with it.
Tale of Two Wastelands is a mod that merges Fallout 3 into New Vegas. This adds a little issue about the Lone Wanderer being the Courier, but I personally don't mind that and I just went on with my time. The story of Tale of Two Wastelands goes ''Born in Vault 101, then did Fallout 3 Story, go into Metro, take train west into the Mojave, then start New Vegas story''. Sure, this messes up the lore of FNV and FO3, BUT. I like this as you get the improvements of Fallout New Vegas BUNDLED with FO3. So if you want Traits and Hardcore Mode in Fallout 3? BAM! This mod is good for you.
Here's the link for the mod: http://taleoftwowastelands.com/

NOTE FOR THE FIRST EDIT, IF YOU WANT TALE OF TWO WASTELANDS, YOU REQUIRE ALL DLC FOR FNV AND FO3 (except the Courier's Stash DLC) AND YOU CAN'T PIRATE ONE GAME TO GET IT TO FUNCTION.

Also, let me just clarify and go into depth why I prefer Fallout New Vegas compared to Fallout 3. It's just the writing and characters. In Fallout 3, it's not bad, just unbelievable, that doesn't mean that I hate the game, dear god no. I love Fallout 3. But Fallout New Vegas' writing is superior in almost every way (when it comes to 3D Fallouts, I own the 3 2D Fallouts which are Tactics, 1 and 2 but I simply couldn't get into them due to reasons of me being too much of a casualized gamer and unable to get into Isometric Turnbased games. I'll probably get into it in the future, but not now). The development team, Obsidian are brilliant and consist of many people who worked on older Fallouts and understand what they're doing related to the lore, writing and other situations in Fallout.
Fallout New Vegas is the more colourful, more true to the original and definitely insanely fun for those who want more Fallout or just want a brilliant FPS-RPG.

reviewText:
I have never written a detailed game review. I have written lots of reviews, but their short and generic. I am so enamored by this game i am going to write a full review

FYI, I have not beat the game, or havnt even really touched most of the places or characters or quests. But after 25 hours with so much to do, I feel I can accuratly review the game.

Overall Impressions:

If you don't want to read a very detailed review of the game, just read this. If you want a detailed review (although u shouldnt be reading reviews and be clicking that buy now button) scroll down a bit.

First off, I have not played FO3, so I have no way to compair weather its a better game than that or not. I had heard about fallout and the mascot for me was easily recognizeable when it came out, but I never had much of an intrest in the game or rpgs. Fallout:NV came out and when my friend got it for Xbox 360, I watched some and it looked interesting, but i was into other games and didnt want to play it. last christmas, while it was on sale, I purchased skyrim, my first rpg taste. Now I realize skyrim isnt as much of an rpg as FO but it got my feet wet, and I loved the setting, being an insanly big Lord of the Rings and Game of Thrones fan. However, i LOVE EFFING SKYRIM TO DEATH. That made me go wow! I bet Fallout is awesome if Skyrim is this good! So i saw it on sale over haloween and i picked it up along with the witcher, payday 2, dmc4. I played mostly pd2 and dmc and witcher and kinda forgot about FO:NV. However, when I did, I wasnt just hooked like i was 2 skyrim. This became the most fun, and overall meaningful game to my playing to date. All of the options are great, there are a lot of different factions all fighting and weaving in and out and picking some sids but not others is fun and challanging. I havn't touched hardcore mode yet but I bet its fun, I just want to focus on enjoying the game right now before I go shoot myself haha! Anways this game is amazing and a MUST OWN. Now onto specifics

Gameplay:
+Many weapons
+GORE
+V.A.T.S. system is a great and not overpowered.
-spriting

The gameplay itself is good, it feels good to shoot and the slight waver in your hand adds to the realism and I personally liked the added challenge. However, not being able to sprint, while not bad, can be annoying as I wish I could rush from cover to cover. I give gameplay 9/10

Visuals:
+Has moments of beauty
+Destroyed wasteland is great and it all affects the mood of the game
-runs on old engin so graphics look mostly outdated
-character models look a bit stiff to me

This game is 4-5 years old and still looks good! However, it does look outdated and abovementioned stuff 7.5/10

Story:
+SO Many options
+tons and tons of ways to progress

To me the story so far is great. Every faction is interesting and your personal story is very cool. The sidemissions IMO are better than main ones, but the main missions are great so thats saying something. 9.5/10

Final verdict:

9.5/10

This is my favorite game of all time. That doesnt mean its a perfect 10. It has a lot of bugs and outdated models, but the game itself is what keeps me going. Anyway thanks for reading!

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying this, if you can't decide if you should get the game or not, buy it! It's worth every penny. I didn't expect to like this game as much as I do. I constantly tell myself that I'll do only one quest, yet that's very difficult to follow through with. I'll end up spending hours on end exploring new locations, doing side quests, and just being an awesome wasteland adventurer. Whether which path you choose, good, bad, NCR, legion, or whatever other choice there is (there's plenty), the game never fails to satisfy. There are so many amazing things about this game that will make you want to keep playing. I recommend doing what I did and buy Ultimate Edition because it will give you all of the great DLCs and extra packs for a very good price. It also will help you at the start of a new game. If you dont have Ultimate Edition though, it's all good. The game is just as great with or without it. The DLCs are amazing, but if you don't have them you'll enjoy the game just as much!

PROS: Amazing story, ALOT of side quests, many places to explore, ALOT of replay value (many different ending outcomes), plenty of humor here and there, Amazing DLCs, and pretty much everything else!

CONS: I can't think of any. o:

You will most likely enjoy this game, I recommend that you play it sometime. 9.5/10

reviewText: This is my favorite game of all time. The customization is limitless and you can take your own personal approach to anything and everything. With such an extensive open world for the base game alone you can play hours upon hours and never even complete a single part of the main story and still have a fulfilling gaming experience. reviewText:
Very few games have grabbed me the way this one does. There's just so much to do, and that's before you start dabbling in mods of which there are many excellent choices, no matter what it is you're looking for. Yes, there are bugs. But by now the majority of them are hammered out, at least in my experience. New Vegas Script Extender and New Vegas Anti-Crash are must-haves and greatly improve the game's stability.

The key here is exploration. Put one foot in front of the other for a little while and you're bound to find something cool to get involved in, whether it's a hostage situation in a ruined city or a showdown in a little desert town. The combat is quite fun, but it's the standard fare. You have guns, there are guys over there and ♥♥♥♥ those guys. Speaking of guns, there's an assload of them. Pistols, shotguns, rifles, assault rifles, SMG's, sniper rifles and even energy weapons, though I myself prefer conventional firearms, the energy weapons are still pretty badass.

The storytelling in this game is superb, with little details everywhere. The story of The Survivalist in Zion Canyon is amazing to read through and experience as you seek out his journal entries across the little hideaways he's established throughout the area. There's also the little things like finding a skeleton laying on a bathroom floor in a tophat clutching a revolver that makes you wonder just what that poor guy's story was. The game manages to be dark and hilarious at the same time which is a tough balancing act to pull off.

Overall this game is excellent and will draw you in and not let go. You'll be stuck on this for hours and hours and you'll love every moment.

9/10

reviewText:
Clearly one of the best Bethesda games.
Upsides
______________________________________________
+Awesome sound
+Awesome main storyline + sidequest's
+Own choises
+Cool followers
+Atmospheric
+Perk's/Upgrades
+Exploring!
+Names (very creative names on, persons, quests, items and so on)
+Nice gear
+Moddable
+Dialogues = perf (and voice acting is also good with some exeptions)
+Pritty little secrets here & there
(there is many more upsides but these are the ones that I just love this game)

Downsides
______________________________________________
-Bugs
-Crashes

The buggs and crashes can be and crashes can be annoying but if you aren't an compleet idiot you can see that the upsides can be worth the trouble.

Simply another huge succes from Bethesda since this is one of the best games ive ever played in my life. And I know I only have 34 houers or so (by the time this reccomendation was made) and I wish that ive would have spent more time on this game since it no doubt deserves it.

Although I have one regret....

Not buying the Ultimate Edition, do that for me please. Only 19.99 euro thats ♥♥♥♥ing sick.

Anyway before I end this recommendation I would like to throw out an little apology for any bad spelling/grammars, spelling in English isen't my strongest side.

10/10 would get hooked on med-x again

reviewText:
THE GAME

wonderful. Truly amazing, I wish this wasn't so underrated, it is a classic, the characters are great, the plot is great, the gameplay? AMAZING its truly amazing and worth your money.

THE TECHNICALS

glitches, glitches, and glitches, occassionally it crashes, but it really is worth it.  sometimes it IS bland and sometimes it feels like it was a bit rushed. i think this game should have had much more play testing and and been development for at least 4 more months. the graphics are a little dated, especially now, and sometimes the actors did not put enough enthusiasm in their acting, but danny trejo, yuri lowenthal, and a few other big name actors fir the roles amazingly. i just hope this makes more people want to join the profession, because Yuri had too many roles. but he did good.



THE PLOT

it's an original and welcomed addition to the fallout franchise, in my personal opinion, it's better than FO3 in almost all aspects, as i mentioned earlier the acting beats FO3 and most AAA titles. but only for the time period. and it is kind of hard to actually talk about the plot without spoiling the experience.





to me at least, this was a show well worth my money, and a gamble worth taking, Fallout: New Vegas, gets a 9.5/10 and Fallout 4, bring it on! :)

reviewText:
This is by far the best RPG game i've played in a long time.
Your character serves purpose in this world.
You kill, and people will start to see you differently whether it be good or bad.
Quests are mutilayered with optional sub-quests.
I love how everyone in this world is killable, regardless of being a quest giver.
Of course it's not recommended to kill everyone you meet, but the fact that you have that choice makes this game feel more like what an open world RPG should be.
I also love that killing is not the only option of getting quests done.
As you level up you can increase your various skills.
some skills such as speech and bartering can be used in conversations with NPCs.
With a high enough speech skill you can persuade people to see things your way, instead of having to put a bullet in their head.
Of course this doesn't apply to every person you meet who is shooting at you.
Anywho, If you have the cash get this game. it's well worth the price and from what i've been told this blows Skyrim out of the water. ♥

reviewText:
If you like FPS-RPG crossovers, this is a quality game to pick up. Turn on true iron sights, install a few mods in the standard practice for Bethesda-engine games, and save often. I'll include a list of my choice mods at the end of the review.

Do save often. Bethesda-engine games are notoriously unstable, and this (built on Oblivion's engine) is no exception!

However, the game has good writing, plays fluidly, and delivers an enjoyably varied experience - especially if you play throught he DLC as well. Highly recommended for fans of Fallout who are not purists at heart (the series has diverged from its isometric RPG roots).

I recommend the following mods:

- Underwater Vault Home New Vegas edition (UMHNV) or Afterschool Special

These are housing mods with a quest to earn their housing. UWHNV requires NVSE (New Vegas Script Extender) and Afterschool special does not. NVSE is worth installing - there are other mods that use it, and it's an invisible modification. (I use the last Beta version, 4.X something and it works well.) UWHNV basically allows you to move the entrance of the home wherever you like and includes a beautiful sorting and display mechanism. Afterschool Special allows you to take over and convert the school in the first town to a home that is simple, compact and effective as well as pretty.

- RHK Companion Cure

Corrects an oversight in Bethesda/Obsidian's companion mechanism, allows you to cure posion in your companions, which is much better than the base mechanics.

- Perk Every Level and Unlimited Traits

This shifts balance somewhat, allowing the player to build as many of the game's provided traits as desired during character creation. (All of them are tradeoffs of one sort or another.) In my case, I didn't want to forego Weird Wasteland because I chose traits that suited my vision of your character. Perk Every Level will build a more powerful character, but also free you from some of the tyrrany of having too many good options or having to ruthlessly specialize into one playstyle.

- DLC: Old World Blues is the best of the set, followed by DLC: Lonesome Road.

The others are certainly not bad, but do not live up to these two. If you get the GOTY edition, you'll get them all, but if you're forced to choose, go with these.

- Other mods, like texture and model replacers to taste.

What you like will vary. I recommend installing the Nexus Mod Manager, and using it to manage your mods as painlessly as possible (everything except NVSE which must be manually installed).

Get it. Get it now. Enjoy it.

reviewText:
War. War never changes. Except for the occasional crash and bugs, but that's typical of a game with little development cycle.

Fallout: New Vegas is a first-person action RPG, much like its predecessor, Fallout 3. Developed by Obsidian Entertainment, it is set in the Mojave Wasteland, closer to where the original games were set. Your customizable character’s a Courier, shot and left for dead by a man named Benny interested in a package you were delivering. Following through your trail for revenge, you find that the major factions in the region--The New California Republic, Caesar’s Legion, and Mr. House--vying for complete control of the Mojave wasteland. It’s up to you whether or not any of the three, or yourself, would take over the Dam.

The NCR is a lot like the US, both the good and the bad. Most of the time, they mean well. In the game, they spread out a lot, using up quite a bit of their resources to cover their new land in the process. This puts them at a disadvantage after the first battle at the Dam against the Legion. Caesar's Legion, in theory, is supposed to be the Roman Empire. But it's filled with misogyny, homophobia, and slavery. There's Mr. House, an expy of Howard Hughes. While he wants to improve humanity in his own way, he's extremely ruthless in his dealings. And there's the Wild Card path, where you set the Mojave down a path of independence and anarchy, alienating the other main factions in the process.

In addition, there are four major DLCs (Dead Money, Honest Hearts, Old World Blues¸ and Lonesome Road), each having its own story, and two additional DLCs (Courier’s Stash--pre-order bonuses--and Gun Runners’ Arsenal—more weapons).

I really enjoyed the game largely due to the writing, along with a lot of replayability. However, I feel that there was a lack of real motivation deciding which faction to assist in taking over Hoover Dam, and I felt that your character lacked a bit of personaity compared to other RPG characters. Even the Lone Wanderer had plenty of personality (c'mon. No. ♥♥♥♥ you."). As mentioned earlier

reviewText:
If the thought of a huge, open, post-apocalyptic wasteland full of interesting places, people and creatures appeals to you then you'll probably love this game.

It's not without its flaws, however. It has more than its fair share of bugs but there are numerous mods and plug-ins and such that can be used to largely negate them. Speaking of mods, there are tons of them available and a lot of them are excellent.

This is also the best scavenging and loot-hoarding game I've ever played, so if that kind of thing floats your boat then that's another plus.

reviewText:
Great game! Tons of ways to customise your character at the start and even more customisation as you play through the game. No two playthroughs are a like which means you will be playing the game over and over again countless times.

As a step up from Fallout 3, you now have iron sights that you can use, as well as a much more varied arsenal of weapons and ammunition types (even more true with the DLC gun runners aresenal).

This is by far my favorite RPG shooter. If you get it, be sure to get all the DLC with it! It's worth it!

reviewText:
Fallout is one of those games that I have fallen in love with. I started with Fallout 3 and at first it fealt dull. Some people will say that they prefer 3 because of its bigger world and more of a wasteland type feel. But with Fallout 3 you get a poor story line, annoying amounts of travelling, and an overall empty experience. None the less. Fallout 3 is still an amazing game it just doesn't feel as energetic.

With Fallout: New Vegas the world feels more alive. With massive amounts of weapons, armor, and mostly MODS. You can play this game for hours and hours. It's not the prettiest game, and it has some bugs but thats what makes Fallout what it is.

If you want to try an RPG and don't want to spend tons of money. Pick this up. I got it in 2010 and still start it up every now and then.

reviewText:
I have looked at this game in my review list for months, of all the titles in my back catalogue Fallout: New Vegas is by far the most daunting. I feel that regardless of to what extent I praise FNV, I will still not be doing it justice.
Fallout as a series has grown from some seriously humble roots, and what it has become is one of the finest post-apocalyptic open world RPGs to date. The world is alive, desperate, detailed, immersive and a true wonder to explore. Within this incredible world are some of the most spectacularly realized NPCs and stories ever conceived by Bethesda. The last time I remember being so aware of the lives around me was when I first played Morrowind.
As if the vanilla game wasn’t amazing enough, the modding community is seemingly limitless. From tower defense, to a first person shooter overhaul, to countless add on stories and scenarios, there are hundreds if not thousands of hours of content to lose yourself in.
The ultimate kicker here is that Fallout: New Vegas is CONSTANTLY on sale. And not just dinky 15% off specials, during any given steam sale, FNV is almost always on sale for 2 or 3 bucks at some point. At this price, it is absolutely ridiculous not to pick up this masterpiece RPG.

reviewText:
I have recently finalized my third playthrough in Fallout: New Vegas. Despite having played other Fallout games in the past, I intend to write a (short and sweet) review that addresses New vegas in a fair manner, and hopefully while attempting to remain unbiased. Here it goes!

General notes
First and foremost, as far as Fallout game comparison goes, New Vegas did not bring a lot of renewing elements to the genre. However, New Vegas does offer a very solid story, an immersive world and a fun atmosphere to be in. Moreover, the world surrounding the player is quite vast.

Game world
New Vegas contains a variety of dungeons for questing, looting and satisfying the player's homicidal needs. These dungeons come in various forms and shapes such as Vaults, caves and buildings. Additionally, there are faction camps, towns and similar places, where the player mainly interacts with NPCs. Above all, I consider The Strip" to be an absolutely terrific aspect of New Vegas. It's quite refreshing to visit The Strip and have a change of scenery after poking around the desert for a while.

Questing
New Vegas provides a large variety of quests that initially aid the player in getting familiarized with the game
date: the various factions and the implications of making certain choices. More quests and quest lines will be available as the player continues to discover new areas
recommended: NPCS and factions. In my experience
hoursPlayed: it is not possible to complete all available quests in a single playthrough. This is primarily caused by faction disputes and the implications of completing a quest for a certain faction. As a result
voteText: an opposing faction might regard you as an enemy
helpfulPercent:
and thus no longer willing to make use of your "services".

DLCs
New Vegas offers a decent number of DLCs that will keep you going for a while. These DLCs often introduce new areas
votesHelpful: weapons
votesTotal:
companions and relevant quest lines.

Bugs
New Vegas is quite a buggy game
votesFunny: probably the buggiest Fallout game I have encountered so far. Game sometimes crashes when attempting to fast travel in the main world. This happens very often in the DLC areas. I have encountered a fair share of bugs with the companions as well. Sometimes they get stuck in walls
commentsCount: doors and rocks
column16:
or sometimes they just completely disappear when entering a dungeon for example.

Graphics
With regard to graphics
column17: there is not much to say about New Vegas. The game simply does not offer a state of the art experience for the graphics enthusiasts out there. However
column18:
certainly not displeasing and good enough to keep the player going.

Final verdict
New Vegas is an absolutely terrific game that provides hours of pleasure for the player. It offers a great story

o jogo é um RPG/FPS mundo aberto.

everywhere)

jogo 8,0/10

reviewText:
Fallout New Vegas, the follow up game after Bethesda took the Fallout series into the action RPG territory with Fallout 3. Unlike Fallout 3 this is an Obsidian game which is both a blessing and a curse but less a curse then generally found with their games. It iterates heavily on Fallout 3 but it does a few things better. Like most Obsidian games FNV has great writing. This translates to better companions, quests and playerchoice compared to Fallout 3. However it lacks some of the personality of Fallout 3 who's start is far superior.

Now onto the game itself. It controls like most Bethesda games, in either first or thirth person, optimized for the former. You most likely fight with either energy or ballistic based weaponry, which uses ammo. Unlike most Bethesda games the game is heavily fragmented into levels. Actions have hard caps, if the cap is at 25, 12, 23 or 24 in a skill will be equally useles. Enemies will level up with so, as will gear but it's less free in that aspect then the later Bethesda games. Another one of thise differences is choice. You can't complete the game 100% in one playthrough. The quests demand choice, generally between shades of grey instead of black or white and there is no optimal ending to the game. Yes unlike Bethesda games this game ends, at the end of the mainquest you'll get the credits roll and that's it.

However in my eyes the jounrey is marvelous. You start in a basic western town, work your way up across the world in an attempt to make it to Vegas. You'll interact with different factions, find loot, hone your skills. Vegas won't be your end however. From there on the game opens up and starts demanding choices who you'll befriend and who you'll kill for profit or pleasure. The game has a lot of choice. Especially modded in true Bethesda custom. I've played a neutral minded combination of a samurai and a cowboy. Focussing on heavy armor, melee weaponry and comboy themed guns. No miniguns, lasersrifles, rocketlaunchers or sneaky powerfist attacks. But I also played a cannabilistic scientist with a knack for punching things or vaporizing them. All is possible, to sneak your way through, talk your way out or if all fails beat some heads to pulp with a steel pipe and then eating their corpses.

reviewText: By far, and I mean FAR- one of the best games ever made. Immersive gameplay, wonderful music, fluent controls, memorable NPC's, a great theme, run-on sentences, a rewarding experience system, freaking cowboys, and well- a lot more. If you haven't checked this game out, play it. It may seem like I am overstating things, but to tell you the truth, this may be the best game I've ever played.\n\n-10/10
