reviewText:
Fallout New Vegas really reminds the player of the original fallouts.

Unlike Fallout 3 (which i highly recommend as well) New Vegas gives you choices that you may be morally conflicted with, yes Fallout 3 had choices in it, all good fallout games have, but New Vegas gives you more options. In addition to more choices the developers have introduced a reputation system, you do something good like help a community you will be liked more, but if you do things they do not like your reputation will go down. All of this matters in the endgame, who will support you depending on what side you took.

Like many of RPG you will encounter people, you will talk to people. Throughout your travels you will meet interesting people you either like or dislike, all characters of importance are interesting, they have a story to tell, from Mr House overlord of the strip to the super mutants in Jacobstown.

The graphics honestly are not anything to brag about. There is little change from Fallout 3, a few things have been brought over. But Fallout has never been known for their graphics, it has been for the story. If you are really bugged by the graphics you could just go and get a mod for it, there are plenty.

VATS is back, along with other gameplay elements that made Fallout 3 popular. There have been changes made as well, more immersive elements have been added, like making ammunition, more crafting options, more weapons types, gambling and many more. I would not be recommending this game if there was no change, but there is change and it is a good change.

Active community, Mods! The community is super active for mods, so many mods mods mods mods.

Lastly the DLC. Lonesome road, Dead money, Old Wolrd Blues and honest hearts. All of them are good in their own respects but this review is looking at the core game, reviews for the DLC's will be on their respective pages or elsewhere.

Fallout New Vegas is a game that is a game I will definitely recommend to anybody that asks.

reviewText:
My Fallout: New Vegas Review.

Yet, another game in the Fallout franchise. Fallout: New Vegas takes place in the Mojave Desert/Wasteland. The Mojave Wasteland isn't as interesting as the D.C. Wasteland in Fallout 3, but it still gives you a good Fallout experience. Now, I've played New Vegas for about 300 hours on the PC, but i have got New Vegas for the XBOX 360 and for PS3. On the PS3 I have played for nearly a 700 hours. XBOX 360 Version was about the same as the PS3 (obviously), but haven't played since my save files got corrupt.

Pro's:
1. Excellent Gameplay. Like i mean this it's really good.
2. A very extensive modding community. Which add's replayability.
3. It's a Fallout game. Who wouldn't like a Fallout game?
4. Has a lot of side quest's. Unlike Fallout 3.
5. Has ironsights on weapons. Unlike Fallout 3.
6. Interesting NPC's. Well not that interesting, but still...

Con's
1. The Mojave Wasteland isn't a very interesting place.
2. The PC port is bull$hit, but you can fix the problem's in 10 minutes or so.
3. Annoying stutters. Many mod's to fix them (30Hz Microstutter's are still noticeable).

I highly recommend you to buy this game. It's hella awesome.

EDIT: Forgot to mention, mods are very easy to install.

EDIT 2: It's September 14, 2015 and only 56 day's remaining till Fallout 4!!

reviewText: Probably my favorite game of all-time. A small slice of post-nuclear Nevada is your playground, with hundreds of well-written, fleshed out characters. Quests in almost every area, dozens of unique, fun weapons and armors, and the ability to play precisely the character you want. A bounty hunter? Done. Brotherhood of Steel ♥♥♥♥ who robs everyone of their advanced tech? You got it. Or maybe an alcoholic with 2 INT and skills in Unarmed? Why not. TONS of replay value. Plus, the modding community is active as hell. Be warned that thanks to Gamebryo, the game is quite buggy (Not as bad as the console version, though) and obviously doesn't look that great. Nothing some mods can't fix, though. Happy trails, courier!

reviewText: Ah, fallout new vegas. A story of grit, deceit, and revenge. The story of a courier who got caught at the bad place at the worst time. After being shot and left for dead, the courier is seemingly brought back from the dead by Doc mitchell. After being let loose into the small town of goodsprings, and learning the ropes of the new survival system, you are set loose into the Nevada wastes. Dead set on revenge, the story is wonderful with many endings. Each one of your actions with the factions, your followers, the main story, the route you take, and even the smallest things (such as replacing a cyborg dogs brain ). The gameplay has not changed too much from fallout 3, using the same engine and all. The endings are all written to perfection, the legion, the ncr, and the independant vegas endings are all satisfying to accomplish. The followers system has been improved on in many ways, the most standout being the new companion wheel. Being able to give your companion stimpaks and orders is much more simple. That and the followers are amazing, and the way you recruit them is more interesting than Fallout 3. The soundtrack is what you would expect from a fallout game, 40s to 50s era music, and its wonderful. How do I know all of this with only 13 hours? I played the ♥♥♥♥ out of the playstation 3 version. The game is a must buy. Also Cazadores are my nightmare fuel.

reviewText:
To all of you oldschool Fallout fans? Forget Fallout 3, this is the actual sequel to our beloved franchise.

The Enclave? Long dead as it should be.
The NCR? Falling apart as they should, no corrupt government will survive forever.

The Super Mutants? Thankfully, we get to bump into the Master's 'Unity' remnants


California? During the game, you'd keep hearing references to the Core Region and the fate of cities and areas such as Sandy Sands, The Hub, New Reno, Broken Valley, and much more.

All the other factions? Fitting right in, like a part of a puzzle. You need one to complete the other, but unfortunately; none of

them match the other. So you'd have to choose which faction to side with. And trust me,  it is hard.

New Vegas? Finally! Other than the Pitt, that was promised to be 'untouched' by the Chinese warheads and Reno. No other cities were mentioned of being saved from the nuclear fallout and chaos brought by the war of 2077. And you get to finally visit a pieace of both living, and dying history in the remains of Las Vegas.

The graphics? I won't say that they're 'next gen'. But they are neither bad.

Plot? THIS is Fallout! By the same developers!

Gameplay? Basically supposed to be the same as Fallout 3's. But it feels way different and unique, in a good way.

If you like Fallout, actual choices, and fighting wanna-be Romans. Buy this game right away!

reviewText:
This is by far the best RPG game i've played in a long time.
Your character serves purpose in this world.
You kill, and people will start to see you differently whether it be good or bad.
Quests are mutilayered with optional sub-quests.
I love how everyone in this world is killable, regardless of being a quest giver.
Of course it's not recommended to kill everyone you meet, but the fact that you have that choice makes this game feel more like what an open world RPG should be.
I also love that killing is not the only option of getting quests done.
As you level up you can increase your various skills.
some skills such as speech and bartering can be used in conversations with NPCs.
With a high enough speech skill you can persuade people to see things your way, instead of having to put a bullet in their head.
Of course this doesn't apply to every person you meet who is shooting at you.
Anywho, If you have the cash get this game. it's well worth the price and from what i've been told this blows Skyrim out of the water. ♥

reviewText:
If you like FPS-RPG crossovers, this is a quality game to pick up. Turn on true iron sights, install a few mods in the standard practice for Bethesda-engine games, and save often. I'll include a list of my choice mods at the end of the review.

Do save often. Bethesda-engine games are notoriously unstable, and this (built on Oblivion's engine) is no exception!

However, the game has good writing, plays fluidly, and delivers an enjoyably varied experience - especially if you play throught he DLC as well. Highly recommended for fans of Fallout who are not purists at heart (the series has diverged from its isometric RPG roots).

I recommend the following mods:

- Underwater Vault Home New Vegas edition (UMHNV) or Afterschool Special

These are housing mods with a quest to earn their housing. UWHNV requires NVSE (New Vegas Script Extender) and Afterschool special does not. NVSE is worth installing - there are other mods that use it, and it's an invisible modification. (I use the last Beta version, 4.X something and it works well.) UWHNV basically allows you to move the entrance of the home wherever you like and includes a beautiful sorting and display mechanism. Afterschool Special allows you to take over and convert the school in the first town to a home that is simple, compact and effective as well as pretty.

- RHK Companion Cure

Corrects an oversight in Bethesda/Obsidian's companion mechanism, allows you to cure posion in your companions, which is much better than the base mechanics.

- Perk Every Level and Unlimited Traits

This shifts balance somewhat, allowing the player to build as many of the game's provided traits as desired during character creation. (All of them are tradeoffs of one sort or another.) In my case, I didn't want to forego Weird Wasteland because I chose traits that suited my vision of your character. Perk Every Level will build a more powerful character, but also free you from some of the tyrrany of having too many good options or having to ruthlessly specialize into one playstyle.

- DLC: Old World Blues is the best of the set, followed by DLC: Lonesome Road.

The others are certainly not bad, but do not live up to these two. If you get the GOTY edition, you'll get them all, but if you're forced to choose, go with these.

- Other mods, like texture and model replacers to taste.

What you like will vary. I recommend installing the Nexus Mod Manager, and using it to manage your mods as painlessly as possible (everything except NVSE which must be manually installed).

Get it. Get it now. Enjoy it.

Like many of RPG you will encounter people, you will talk to people. Throughout your travels you will meet interesting people you either like or dislike, all characters of importance are interesting, they have a story to tell, from Mr House overlord of the strip to the super mutants in Jacobstown.

The graphics honestly are not anything to brag about. There is little change from Fallout 3, a few things have been brought over. But Fallout has never been known for their graphics, it has been for the story. If you are really bugged by the graphics you could just go and get a mod for it, there are plenty.

VATS is back, along with other gameplay elements that made Fallout 3 popular. There have been changes made as well, more immersive elements have been added, like making ammunition, more crafting options, more weapons types, gambling and many more. I would not be recommending this game if there was no change, but there is change and it is a good change.

Active community, Mods! The community is super active for mods, so many mods mods mods mods.

Lastly the DLC. Lonesome road, Dead money, Old Wolrd Blues and honest hearts. All of them are good in their own respects but this review is looking at the core game, reviews for the DLC's will be on their respective pages or elsewhere.

Fallout New Vegas is a game that is a game I will definitely recommend to anybody that asks.

reviewText:
As one of the first, modern open-world RPGs I've been able to play in a LONG while, Fallout: New Vegas has got me hooked. As the first Fallout game I've ever owned and played, I guess I can't say too much about New Vegas in comparison to its predecessors, but I think the game is just amazing overall. So far, the main story is great, the combat is spread out and fun, and there's just a lot to do. I would say that a half of the time I've spent playing the game I've been exploring the landscape for loot and discovering new places that aren't on the map which then leads to new quests. Character development is also another enjoyable factor of the game I've found whether you're going with a stealthy, assassin like character or a full out explosives one. Much like what Bethesda did in Skyrim, all the choices are yours to make.

Although I have played this game for quite a bit of time (some will probably disagree, like those with 400+), I feel like I have barely scratched the surface of this game. I'm looking forward to finishing it in the future and then eagerly waiting for Fallout 4's release

9.5/10

reviewText: Ah, fallout new vegas. A story of grit, deceit, and revenge. The story of a courier who got caught at the bad place at the worst time. After being shot and left for dead, the courier is seemingly brought back from the dead by Doc mitchell. After being let loose into the small town of goodsprings, and learning the ropes of the new survival system, you are set loose into the Nevada wastes. Dead set on revenge, the story is wonderful with many endings. Each one of your actions with the factions, your followers, the main story, the route you take, and even the smallest things (such as replacing a cyborg dogs brain ). The gameplay has not changed too much from fallout 3, using the same engine and all. The endings are all written to perfection, the legion, the ncr, and the independant vegas endings are all satisfying to accomplish. The followers system has been improved on in many ways, the most standout being the new companion wheel. Being able to give your companion stimpaks and orders is much more simple. That and the followers are amazing, and the way you recruit them is more interesting than Fallout 3. The soundtrack is what you would expect from a fallout game, 40s to 50s era music, and its wonderful. How do I know all of this with only 13 hours? I played the ♥♥♥♥ out of the playstation 3 version. The game is a must buy. Also Cazadores are my nightmare fuel.

reviewText:
To all of you oldschool Fallout fans? Forget Fallout 3, this is the actual sequel to our beloved franchise.

The Enclave? Long dead as it should be.
The NCR? Falling apart as they should, no corrupt government will survive forever.

The Super Mutants? Thankfully, we get to bump into the Master's 'Unity' remnants


California? During the game, you'd keep hearing references to the Core Region and the fate of cities and areas such as Sandy Sands, The Hub, New Reno, Broken Valley, and much more.

All the other factions? Fitting right in, like a part of a puzzle. You need one to complete the other, but unfortunately; none of

them match the other. So you'd have to choose which faction to side with. And trust me,  it is hard.

New Vegas? Finally! Other than the Pitt, that was promised to be 'untouched' by the Chinese warheads and Reno. No other cities were mentioned of being saved from the nuclear fallout and chaos brought by the war of 2077. And you get to finally visit a pieace of both living, and dying history in the remains of Las Vegas.

The graphics? I won't say that they're 'next gen'. But they are neither bad.

Plot? THIS is Fallout! By the same developers!

Gameplay? Basically supposed to be the same as Fallout 3's. But it feels way different and unique, in a good way.

If you like Fallout, actual choices, and fighting wanna-be Romans. Buy this game right away!

reviewText:
After the wide critical acclaim and finacial success of Bethesda's Fallout 3, it was only a matter of time before a follow up was to be produced. This follow up developed by Obsidian Entertainement would not only meet fan expectations across the board but raise the bar of quality and world building for Western RPG's as a genre.

What makes New Vegas a great game compared to it's contempararies is the level of depth and thoughtfulness when it came to presenting it's setting. The people, towns, and factions are all handled incredibly realistically, to the extent where each settlement has it's own food source and way of income. Comparitively in Fallout 3, such details are completely glossed over, leaving some very impractical settlements scattered about the wasteland.

Since this game uses the same engine as Fallout 3, Obsidian had the luxury of improving where they Bethesda left off. As a result, players have the ability to aim down the sight of their weapons, switch between different ammo types, weapon modding, companion quests/companion perks, and a hardcore mode which offers even more gameplay mechanics to the mix.

Personally, I'd say my favorite aspect of New Vegas is the thriving mod community that continues to still produce more content on already 100 + hour experience.

If you're into games that present world worth engaging yourself in as well a wealth of opportunities for player expression, then New Vegas is definitely worth the purchase. Easily one of the best games of last generation.

reviewText:
The dark humor combined with a retro 50s vibe set in a futuristic world makes for a unique experience that's just waiting to be explored. Blowing off a Mutant's head with your Hunting Rifle while listening to your radio is throughly satisfying but be aware that this game isn't for everyone. If you've played Skyrim and are expecting more of the lively, beautiful and colorful landscapes of Tamriel in New Vegas, you're in for a disappointment.

New Vegas is not pretty. It's run-down, gloomy, abandoned and depressing. But that's the point. You're supposed to feel isolated and feel out of place in the vast wasteland of Nevada. This is by no means, the game's con but rather, its pro. Obsidian nails the feeling of a post-apocalyptic world and the characters that fill this world is where New Vegas truly shines. You'll come across hundreds of NPCs, each with their own interesting, serious and often, hilarious backstories. It's these characters that bring the game and its story to life. On that note, the story is decent and keeps the game moving and depending on your choices, the game's ending will be affected. As a result, the game offers abundant replay value and can easily extend over 60 hours and counting (that's being really conservative).

The choices you make aren't superficial like most games that advertise a choice system." In New Vegas
date: your choices have hard consequences whether it's making a faction hate/like you or killing off an NPC. Yes
recommended: you can kill ANY character you see in the game (besides children
hoursPlayed: although there's a mod that allows you to kill children as well) so the choices are quite unlimited. Doing this can cause you to fail certain quests because a specific character is dead so you should probably think twice before letting someone bite the bullet.\n\nGraphically

votesHelpful: the game looks good and mods can do wonders for the game and completely change how the game looks
votesTotal: making for an even more immersive experience. However
votesFunny: New Vegas shouldn't be looked upon for its graphics. It should be judged by how much flexibility and options it gives to the player in terms of its characters and story. That's where most of the satisfaction is going to come from.\n\nIf you're sitting on the fence for this game
commentsCount: go ahead and pick it up

column18: I couldn't put it down. Fallout: New Vegas is a really unprecedented experience and one that I feel many people should give a chance.\n\nI look forward to the next installment in the Fallout franchise."

reviewText:
As if it weren't clear enough already from it being on the same engine with the same controls and having the same thing where all the female characters look like a more boyish Natalie Portman, New Vegas is functionally just an expansion pack of Fallout 3, and I said everything I needed to say about Fallout 3 in my Fallout 3 review of Fallout 3.

There is one interesting new feature, though: hardcore mode, which has the need to regularly eat, sleep, and drink while traveling, which sounded like fun, in a Bear Grylls-y kind of way. And this is a role-playing game, so let's mother♥♥♥♥ing roleplay!

Day One

Woke up in a doctor's office with some guy telling me I'd been shot in the head and may have suffered brain damage, but I've learned not to trust the opinion of giant mustachioed spider people, so I made my excuses and left.

The town I found myself in was pleasant enough, with all kinds of useful supplies that residents were just giving away - that is to say, not supervising. But everyone seemed to think I wanted to go in pursuit of the bloke who shot my brain, but I'd have thought the fact that he shot me in the brain was a ♥♥♥♥ing good reason to not pursue the guy.

I keep hearing about this New Vegas place that sounds like a happening kind of town, daddy-o, and the most direct route is north, so after loading myself down with other people's packed lunches I set off on the north road with a song in my heart and was immediately eaten by giant killer flies. Starting to feel I might not be the master of my own destiny.

Fine, whatever. After reloading - I mean, err, reincarnating - I went south instead, and thankfully no cosmic anvils descended from on high. After a peaceful walk through the lovely countryside, I began to feel thirsty, so I drank some pilfered soda bottles that boasted a +H2O effect and was about to set off again when I suddenly became dehydrated. While double-checking that I wasn't wearing ♥♥♥♥ing arctic gear, I noticed that my bottles of purified water had a -H2O effect. Oh, I see, the H2O stat refers to how much water you need, not how much you have. Well, that's ♥♥♥♥ing confusing. When does a plus sign ever indicate a negative effect? Wait a second, drinking soda makes me more thirsty? How does that make any ♥♥♥♥ing sense? Is it made of seawater?

Anyway, the sun was hanging low in the sky like the carrot being dangled from the fishing rod of destiny, and I needed somewhere to sleep. Fortunately, I stumbled upon a repurposed prison populated by the gang whose members have been randomly attacking me all day, but I didn't bear a grudge, because they'd all learned combat from watching their hamsters playfighting and died easier than the ♥♥♥♥ing flies. They wouldn't let me in until I paid 100 caps, though. I'm pretty sure Disneyland doesn't charge that much, so I turned away and moved on. Then I stood on a mine and my legs blew off. Perspective thus gained, I sheepishly dragged myself back to prison and gave them all my money, but then the prison doctor wanted another 75 quid to glue my legs back on. But just as fate had lodged its spiked butt plug as far as it could go, the kindly prison storekeeper was nice enough to just give away 200 caps out of a strongbox in a locked room behind several armed guards. So with a net profit and two shiny new legs fresh from the wrapper, I settled down that night on a prison mattress that smelled like it'd seen its fair share of brutal romantic conquests.

Day Two

As I stole breakfast, I was beginning to sense some hostility from these murderers. I decided there and then that I had to stop stealing things. While there didn't seem to be any negative consequences for having low karma, it was sucking all the survivalist fun out of the game -- I mean, my life.

I set off on a southeasterly direction and was attacked by bandits who I could now kill from a smug position of moral superiority. Then I took all their stuff, which isn't stealing because they attacked me, making it mine by international law of go ♥♥♥♥ yourselves.

I've been using a pistol and rifle and found myself relying less on the VATS aiming system, because I don't want to have to go to make a cup of tea every time I pull the trigger, but when manually aiming, my pistol seemed more accurate than my rifle, because the rifle sights look like I'm aiming down a ♥♥♥♥ing brick.

I reached the next settlement on the road to find it taken over by Roman legionaries, but they seemed like quite friendly chaps who just want me to admire their modern art project, which unfortunately involved nailing everyone who could have sold me supplies or a bed for the night to bits of wood. So after letting one of their dogs bite my arm off, I hiked northeast to the next settlement, where I found a doctor for my arm and a kindly old couple who let me drink out of their toilet.

Day Three

The morning got off to a flying start when I blundered into a hostage situation at the next town between local law enforcement and some gang who had taken two of their members hostage. I managed to convince the leader of the soldiers to let me try negotiating, but really I only wanted to loot the abandoned buildings for water and breakfast cereal. I felt bad on my way out, though, so I shot one of the gang members in the head and ran behind the soldiers as the battle broke out. Tee hee. But then the soldiers massacred the gang with no difficulty. You lazy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s! What did you need me for? They didn't even shoot the hostages, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I didn't realize the gangs were hiring from girl scout troops.

Anyway, I was now within groping distance of my destination, and I strolled confidently up to the magnificent steel barricade of New Vegas. Then I had to stroll confidently all the way around the ♥♥♥♥ing thing looking for the entrance. Eventually that got sorted out, and I found myself in a delightful little suburb on the way into New Vegas proper, which security wouldn't let me into because I didn't have 2,000 caps on me, which I estimated was slightly more money than there existed in the world. But I'd come too far to pull out and spoil the bedspread now, so nearby I found a bar willing to employ me to collect some debts from some locals, and then I just kept all the money for myself. Ha! Stupid trusting jerks.

And then I made it. I stepped out into the glittering lights of the city, the towering buildings noisy monoliths to the sheer potential of why the ♥♥♥♥ can't I move? The game froze up! I mean, my life froze up! I mean, all that radioactive toilet water must have given me some kind of paralyzing - oh, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to this. Roleplaying in Fallout 3 is difficult enough with the interface and the terrifying fixed-eye contact conversations without it bugging out as well, and it will take more than having to stop for a sandwich and a ♥♥♥♥ every now and again to make Fallout 3 more immersive. Maybe if you ground it into powder and dissolved it in a swimming pool, but it'd probably only turn the water brown.

reviewText:
Fallout has always been rugged and uneven, both as a series and as individual games. The first two titles regularly feature on the greatest games lists despite the unfinished, buggy and censored-in-EU nature of the second game in particular, which at the time gave a sadomasochistic mix of pain and pleasure. The legend is justified, of course, with complex mechanics married to equally complex storytelling. The original vision mixed surreal elements and pop-culture references with pitch-black realism and a psychotic wit. The series was awoken from slumber by Bethesda with Fallout 3, which met with success and acclaim at the time, triumphing over the scepticism of the community. Whatever the merits of 3 as a game, it was ultimately undone by paper-thin, artificial writing with the finest elements being simple allusions to what came before.

With New Vegas Bethesda did the best possible decision by giving the development duties to Obsidian Entertainment and the brilliant veterans within. New Vegas is a classic Fallout in the good and the bad. The game was released in an incomplete state to say the least, with a rotating head greeting players in a moment of true horror comedy... with many such moments following. Apart from the glitches there was much cut content which the mod community has done its best to restore. This is all classic Fallout indeed as is fortunately the game beneath the problems. Instead of merely repeating or referencing the previous entries Obisidian chose to reimagine the Fallout as a post-apocalyptic Western, building on tradition without being trapped in it.

The gameplay is by and large the same as in 3, with added subtleties, some of which were inspired by Fallout 3 mods. The optional Hardcore mode made food, water and sleep vital which was a pleasure-adding limitation. The perk tree was changed more and the skill tree a bit less, mostly for the better. Crafting is fun but not always necessary and stealth is simply much too powerful. Chems and alcohol give extremely useful boosts and addictions are so easy to cure that The Courier will most likely spend most of the game high out of his mind, yet reasoning calmly all the while. Certain perks are virtually mandatory with other ones being useless if not outright broken. Charisma is infamous for being the dump stat with virtually no use, Karma does not affect anything, a high Speech skill outweighs all the in-game roleplaying choices, the difficulty slider is both crude and shallow -- et cetera, et cetera ad nauseaum. There is only so much mods can do.

But while the mechanics can be criticized to no end New Vegas is a truly great game, one no games lover should pass. Whatever it" is
date: the magic that makes any great game an another world
recommended: New Vegas has it. No magic can be dissected and analyzed but one can try to describe it. Thinking back on my time in the Mojave it is the people I remember
hoursPlayed: from the dignified to the funny... and the brutal. The articulate megalomania of Caesar
voteText: the resigned and humane smart-assery of ghoul mechanic Raul Tejada and the swanky sociopathy of Benny are all unforgettable
helpfulPercent: as is Mr. New Vegas
votesHelpful: the greatest gentleman to ever grace the radio waves. Even secondary characters like a certain ghoul prophet or an extremely likeable Elvis impersonator leading a gang of Elvis impersonators leave a permanent impression. The DLCs follow suit
votesTotal: with Joshua Graham in Honest Hearts being a personal favorite. He has a history of atrocities he tries to atone for but finds it easiest to do so by committing even more atrocities. He describes his antagonist
votesFunny: the raider chief Salt-Upon-Wounds thus: "He is a butcher. I feel the godless fire burning in him well
commentsCount: for I have felt it too." Joshua wants to kill the things he does not accept in himself
column16: which is a very human thing to do
column17: for better or for worse.\n\nAll these characters are given true life by a cast that can only be described as unique. There are the famed veterans
column18: such as Keith Szarabajka as Joshua Graham but then there are many unusual suspects like Kris Kristofferson as Chief Hanlon or Wayne Newton as Mr. New Vegas that all make me wish they would find alternate careers in voice acting. This applies in particular to the greatest surprise in the cast
column19: Matthew Perry as Benny. This is his only VA performance to date but he brings such reptilian
column20: smooth-talking calculations to the table it is very nearly enough to make one think he has been miscast all these years in his other work.\n\nAs for the graphics
column21: sounds and much else the only thing that needs to be said is that there are mods for it all
column22: more than enough to make the game your own. The DLCs are some of the best I've seen
column23: the survival-horror-meets-casino-heist of Dead Money and the loopy Old World Blues being equally great for their very different reasons
column24: with the always underrated Honest Hearts being my favorite of the bunch. (There is a fourth
column25: Lonesome Road
column26: but I have yet to play it.) The mods also fix all the bugs and the glitches and the JSawyer mod rebalances the game extremely well. Given the package price at which New Vegas sells the only conceivable reason to not play is the damage it will do to your free time. New Vegas may not have been developed by Bethesda but is nonetheless the greatest "Live another life
column27: in another world" gaming experience associated with them."

reviewText:
Surprisingly, this game was heavily criticised by Fallout fans, for being no where near as big as Fallout 3. Personally, I think New Vegas is the better of the two, and here's why.

New Vegas, whilst it isn't as large as Fallout 3, still packs an awful lot of content into it's self. Whilst most of the map is a barren landscape, New Vegas is FULL of hiden quests, items, easter eggs and just swarming with things to do.

Whilst it doesn't add much new to the Fallout series, in no means does it feel like a Fallout 3 copy. The story is great, full of twists and turns and most importatnly, player options. You get to choose how you want the grand finale to go, wheter it's the easiest way or the hardest. After you complete the main Act's, you still have a ton of places to explore, quests to solve, and DLC to download!

My only problem with this game, is linked quests. For example, to progress one Main Act quest, you must complete either a very long side quest, or various little side quests that usually offer no impact on the player or story. This is not a fun way to play, and it feels like the game is forcing these quests on me, rather than letting me have the freedom of choice, like the title the game holds dear to its self.

+ Story is very interesting, player involvement heavily influences it
+ Hundreds of hours of content, including 6 DLC expansions
+ You really feel as if you make in impact in the game universe
+ The Wild Wasteland perk. Nuff said.

- Alot of grinding is required for some parts of the game
- Enforced quests are not fun
- AI is sometimes sloppy, but nothing too major

9.5/10

reviewText:
Fallout New Vegas is yet another game about Skyrim with guns, but this one is different, and in a lot of good ways, the world created is a charming yet surprisingly deep land of politics and interesting characters all around.

Instead of writing an essay about this i'm going to create a list of Positives and Negatives, I know when you're just looking to see if a game is worth playing you usually don't want to read all that much.

Positives

- The story always seems to be moving forwards and never seems to slow down always introducing new and interesting characters to meet.
- The art style is beautiful, the world in general is extremely bright and colourful and everything is outline with more of a red tone than most games, this helps to differentiate its style from the crowd and really makes it a pleasure to view.
- The characters are all interesting and I always found myself wanting to learn more about them and their origins.
- The relationship between Boone and his wife is great.

Negatives
- The relationship between Boone and his wife might turn off some viewers.
- The 'shooting' dynamic is interesting in some areas but it does get rid of some of the tension from certain battles.
- The game ends on an extreme cliffhanger
- Sound was nothing special.


I would recommend New Vegas to most people if only because it is extremely short at this stage, it won't take you long to power through the 30000 quests, however if you don't like cliffhangers you should definitely hold off on playing New Vegas

reviewText: Orth, 3000 years in the future. The planet is a radioactive wasteland inhabited by ska-criminals, sentient rat mutants, and Fearum's deadly Waster clan. The Daybringer is the proxy agent for extrasolarian reverse-aging gas-cloud lifeforms which intend on re-arranging the events of all timelines so that only one timeline remains, freeing up valuable multiverse real estate. Jack and Jill are the most advanced paired AIs ever conceived, on a mission to sift through memories and sort out where and when The Techno Device is. Dzang-Sarang is an extradimensional refugee hoping that the other half of his body shows up at some point. The ruthless Praetarch Unless has made a deal with The Daybringer to spare this timeline, but at what cost? Dr. Tuce Dopeshow is the only man who has a handle on what's going on but he's been dead for centuries. You are Abe Stahl, a salt-and-pepper haired grifter who just wants a root beer. Chinese language only, all characters voiced by Frank Yang. 8/10

reviewText: Even after the release of Fallout 4, I still find myself coming back to this game.  This game is the best of the modern Fallout RPG's.  It improves upon some of the more lackluster elements of Fallout 3 by having some more interesting venues to explore and removing the annoying green tinge to everything in the Wasteland, but still keeps some of the best RPG mechanics of this game that Fallout 4 will do away with, such as the karma and reputation systems.  There's memorable characters and locales to be seen in this game, and it is well worth the price of admission.

reviewText: While Fallout: New Vegas has its good moments here and there, I can't help but feel like it was simply a copy of an already successful Fallout 3, including people Fallout 3 mods such as the Workbenches and Cooking mods to name a few then adding a sepia filter to the game world. The scale of the Fallout: New Vegas world compared to Fallout 3 is tiny, if you take into consideration how much of the map was really used... The combat stayed pretty much the same, there wasn't really much that changed, the war certainly didn't... If I had not played Fallout 3 then Fallout: New Vegas would have been all that that I had experienced in Fallout 3, minus the NPC's who brought so much life to the game. Fallout: New Vegas' NPC's were really lacking, both in depth and variety, and I couldn't help but feel that the developers rushed the game adding hundreds of thingamabobs here and there to fill the vast expanse. That's the difference between FNV and FO3, in FO3 one thing would lead to another, which blended in seamlessly whereas FNV you've go from one spot then be like what now"."

reviewText:
Best Fallout game, with alot of interesting quests, and a huge Wasteland to explore. The story this time is based along the war between the New California Republic (NCR), and the Legion. Both have their strengths and weaknesses, and you can join whichever you want to complete the game, or go through and independant New Vegas, and kick both of them out of Nevada. A vast improvement over Fallout 3 in terms of weapons, iron sights, and locations. The characters are quite memorable, and the companions are badasses if you get them the right gear. Both the Brotherhood of Steel and the Enclave make appearances, but in vastly dimmed down appearances than their Fallout 3 counterparts. Which is a shame, as I like the Fallout 3 Brotherhood better than New Vegas's.

There are four pieces of DLC for New Vegas, but they all have their ups and downs.
Dead Money is an extremely confusing, and creepy DLC to play, but gives you a good few hours of gameplay. This was my least favorite of the four.
Honest Hearts is my favorite, as it gives you a huge part of Utah to explore (namely Zion National Park), gives you some awesome armor to wear, and has some pretty awesome characters, namely the Burned Man himself, Joshua Graham. A must play even just to get the Desert Ranger Armor.
Old World Blues was a pretty standard run to this place, grab something, run to this place grab this, and so on and so forth. The one thing that sets this out from the rest is the Brains"
date: a group of former scientists from before the Great War who placed their brains in robots so they could continue living. I won't spoil anything
recommended: but their entire dialogue is absolutely hilarious to hear

reviewText:
Bethesda Softworks' release of Fallout 3 in 2008 went a long way in reviving a series which looked to have been milked for all it was worth, and brought a new set of fans for the series. Yet, while the new fans were being entertained by Fallout 3, some of the older fanbase – including myself – bemoaned the game for its poor story and dialogue, the liberties taken with the canon, and the disappointing ending. When the development of Fallout: New Vegas was announced, I must admit that I felt a bit of trepidation. Obsidian Entertaiment was composed of members of the Fallout development team when Black Isle was at its prime, but were they the right people to take up the mantle of a new Fallout game?

In the development of Fallout: New Vegas, Obsidian drew in elements from the incomplete game which was to have been the third instalment of the main series, Van Buren, with various changes to their implementation to deal with the smaller geographical area. Gameplay-wise, though, Fallout: New Vegas strongly resembles Fallout 3, and could be best described as a refined variant of the first/third-person action role-playing action that distinguished Fallout 3 from its predecessors in the series. The skill set has been cleaned up somewhat, removing the Small Guns and Big Guns categories, and placing their weapons into the Guns and Explosives skills accordingly. The new Survival skill ties into the expanded crafting mechanics, and is of particular concern to the new Hardcore mode, in which the character must eat, sleep and drink, in which ammunition has weight as in the original Fallout games, and in which healing takes place over time, rather than being instantaneous.

In an increased attempt to make non-weapon skills useful, the crafting mechanic has been expanded to include the ability to hand-load ammunition using shell casings, powder and lead at a reloading bench, along with cooking and the production of poisons at a campfire. The reloading mechanic is particularly welcome, allowing for the recycling of excess stockpiled ammunition, as well as the casting of rare ammunition types, including certain enhanced ammunition exclusive to the reloading bench. Meanwhile, the cooking mechanic gives a new use to those boxes of Cram which seem to be littered around the wasteland, allowing a skilled player to produce food which can heal more effectively and, in Hardcore Mode, which satiates the character's hunger for longer.

Another new addition to the series is the “true ironsights” configurable option, which ties into a general tightening-up of the shooting mechanics. VATS has been weakened from Fallout 3, and in its place, the shooting mechanics feel somewhat more satisfying, at least at long range, where long rifles feel a bit more useful than they did in Fallout 3. Indeed, weapons under the Guns skill feel a lot more capable of getting one to the end of the game than in Fallout 3, and it is perfectly possible for somebody to focus on one weapon skill – apart from possibly Explosives - and to have few problems proceeding onwards.

The biggest way in which Fallout: New Vegas is distinct to its immediate predecessor is that it feels like a character- and dialogue-oriented game, rather than the exploration-oriented approach of Fallout 3. One of my biggest disappointments with Fallout 3 was its rather poor storyline, in which one felt railroaded into a set of actions, even when they didn't make logical sense for your character, and which worked to the detriment of the rest of the game. Fallout: New Vegas, on the other hand, allows for a greater amount of flexibility with the storyline, with four distinct paths for one to set on, a lot of choices to make in the wasteland, and far more logical consistency than Fallout 3. This does come at a cost, as the start of the game is very linear in terms of exploration, with powerful creatures making progression directly towards New Vegas difficult, but as this approach was taken – albeit more subtly – in both Fallout and Fallout 2, so this will only be a big concern to the players who enjoyed Fallout 3 primarily because of the exploration elements.

Another area which Fallout: New Vegas improves on is the portrayal of its characters. Unlike Fallout 3, in which most of the main characters felt bland or clichéd, Fallout: New Vegas takes more care with several of its characters, giving them a bit more life beyond being simple quest markers. This is of particular note when it comes to the leaders of each faction, and also with the companion characters, all of which possess a well-crafted backstory and a personal quest which progresses their characterisation further. This makes a good comparison to the pack mule approach taken by Fallout 3, and even, to a lesser extent, by Fallout and Fallout 2.

A welcome change to the dynamic of the game is the lessened importance of the karma meter, displaced by the Fallout 2 approach of community reputations, which has been expanded to allow for a broader variety of different reputations. A greater logical consistency is created with NPC reactions, something which felt lacking in Fallout 3. What's more, this allows for a bit more moral ambiguity within the game universe, a far cry from the rather binary set of moral interactions which resulted from Fallout 3's reliance on the karma meter.

Aesthetically, Fallout: New Vegas is not particularly impressive. Fallout 3, also built on the Gamebryo engine, was not particularly impressive. Fallout 3, also built on the Gamebryo engine, was not particularly graphically impressive when it made its appearance in 2008. With no significant improvements to graphics, Fallout: New Vegas looks mediocre, particularly in the wake of extremely GPU-intensive but especially flashy game engines for the PC in the interim. Sounds are effective, but not particularly striking, and simply serve their purpose without going beyond the call of duty.

Inon Zur's backing music from Fallout 3 returns, with a few extra tracks added to the mix. Again, I'd argue that this music is just there to create the right sense of ambience, and rarely goes beyond that purpose. Some Fallout and Fallout 2 players will note the return of some of the music of Mark Morgan from these games, but again, this music always seemed to just serve a purpose with the exception of a few tracks which didn't make it into Fallout: New Vegas.

As with Fallout 3, a healthy number of licensed tracks make their way into the game via the Pip-Boy 3000's radio. Some players may prefer this music to the standard soundtrack, while others may tire quickly of the repetition of the small library of tracks, but it's nice to see the option retained. The music also creates the ambience of civilisation within communities, so in that sense, it's still worth having within the game.

Unfortunately, there is one very negative area in which Fallout: New Vegas has followed in the footsteps of its predecessors.  Fallout: New Vegas is still not entirely free of bugs, with graphical glitches and clipping issues still remaining. While the Fallout series has not had a reputation for faultless programming, partially a consequence of its extensive scope, it's disappointing and jarring to have an enemy – or worse, yourself – stuck in the side of a rock with no way to escape.

Nevertheless, Fallout: New Vegas certainly progresses the series, working on the framework of Fallout 3, while taking more influence from the preceding Fallout games and instituting some of the visions that were planned for Van Buren. Paradoxically, in terms of the series progression, it may have made more sense to term this to be the third instalment in the main series, and have named Fallout 3 something along the lines of Fallout: Capital Wasteland. Either way, Fallout: New Vegas is a reasonably well-crafted and frequently fun game which only suffers from the minor disappointment of persistent bugs.

reviewText:
Bethesda Softworks' release of Fallout 3 in 2008 went a long way in reviving a series which looked to have been milked for all it was worth, and brought a new set of fans for the series. Yet, while the new fans were being entertained by Fallout 3, some of the older fanbase – including myself – bemoaned the game for its poor story and dialogue, the liberties taken with the canon, and the disappointing ending. When the development of Fallout: New Vegas was announced, I must admit that I felt a bit of trepidation. Obsidian Entertaiment was composed of members of the Fallout development team when Black Isle was at its prime, but were they the right people to take up the mantle of a new Fallout game?

In the development of Fallout: New Vegas, Obsidian drew in elements from the incomplete game which was to have been the third instalment of the main series, Van Buren, with various changes to their implementation to deal with the smaller geographical area. Gameplay-wise, though, Fallout: New Vegas strongly resembles Fallout 3, and could be best described as a refined variant of the first/third-person action role-playing action that distinguished Fallout 3 from its predecessors in the series. The skill set has been cleaned up somewhat, removing the Small Guns and Big Guns categories, and placing their weapons into the Guns and Explosives skills accordingly. The new Survival skill ties into the expanded crafting mechanics, and is of particular concern to the new Hardcore mode, in which the character must eat, sleep and drink, in which ammunition has weight as in the original Fallout games, and in which healing takes place over time, rather than being instantaneous.

In an increased attempt to make non-weapon skills useful, the crafting mechanic has been expanded to include the ability to hand-load ammunition using shell casings, powder and lead at a reloading bench, along with cooking and the production of poisons at a campfire. The reloading mechanic is particularly welcome, allowing for the recycling of excess stockpiled ammunition, as well as the casting of rare ammunition types, including certain enhanced ammunition exclusive to the reloading bench. Meanwhile, the cooking mechanic gives a new use to those boxes of Cram which seem to be littered around the wasteland, allowing a skilled player to produce food which can heal more effectively and, in Hardcore Mode, which satiates the character's hunger for longer.

Another new addition to the series is the “true ironsights” configurable option, which ties into a general tightening-up of the shooting mechanics. VATS has been weakened from Fallout 3, and in its place, the shooting mechanics feel somewhat more satisfying, at least at long range, where long rifles feel a bit more useful than they did in Fallout 3. Indeed, weapons under the Guns skill feel a lot more capable of getting one to the end of the game than in Fallout 3, and it is perfectly possible for somebody to focus on one weapon skill – apart from possibly Explosives - and to have few problems proceeding onwards.

One of my biggest disappointments with Fallout 3 was its rather poor storyline, in which one felt railroaded into a set of actions, even when they didn't make logical sense for your character, and which worked to the detriment of the rest of the game. Fallout: New Vegas, on the other hand, allows for a greater amount of flexibility with the storyline, with four distinct paths for one to set on, a lot of choices to make in the wasteland, and far more logical consistency than Fallout 3. This does come at a cost, as the start of the game is very linear in terms of exploration, with powerful creatures making progression directly towards New Vegas difficult, but as this approach was taken – albeit more subtly – in both Fallout and Fallout 2, so this will only be a big concern to the players who enjoyed Fallout 3 primarily because of the exploration elements.

Another area which Fallout: New Vegas improves on is the portrayal of its characters. Unlike Fallout 3, in which most of the main characters felt bland or clichéd, Fallout: New Vegas takes more care with several of its characters, giving them a bit more life beyond being simple quest markers. This is of particular note when it comes to the leaders of each faction, and also with the companion characters, all of which possess a well-crafted backstory and a personal quest which progresses their characterisation further. This makes a good comparison to the pack mule approach taken by Fallout 3, and even, to a lesser extent, by Fallout and Fallout 2.

A welcome change to the dynamic of the game is the lessened importance of the karma meter, displaced by the Fallout 2 approach of community reputations, which has been expanded to allow for a broader variety of different reputations. A greater logical consistency is created with NPC reactions, something which felt lacking in Fallout 3. What's more, this allows for a bit more moral ambiguity within the game universe, a far cry from the rather binary set of moral interactions which resulted from Fallout 3's reliance on the karma meter.

Aesthetically, Fallout: New Vegas is not particularly impressive. Fallout 3, also built on the Gamebryo engine, was not particularly impressive. Fallout 3, also built on the Gamebryo engine, was not particularly graphically impressive when it made its appearance in 2008. With no significant improvements to graphics, Fallout: New Vegas looks mediocre, particularly in the wake of extremely GPU-intensive but especially flashy game engines for the PC in the interim. Sounds are effective, but not particularly striking, and simply serve their purpose without going beyond the call of duty.

Inon Zur's backing music from Fallout 3 returns, with a few extra tracks added to the mix. Again, I'd argue that this music is just there to create the right sense of ambience, and rarely goes beyond that purpose. Some Fallout and Fallout 2 players will note the return of some of the music of Mark Morgan from these games, but again, this music always seemed to just serve a purpose with the exception of a few tracks which didn't make it into Fallout: New Vegas.

As with Fallout 3, a healthy number of licensed tracks make their way into the game via the Pip-Boy 3000's radio. Some players may prefer this music to the standard soundtrack, while others may tire quickly of the repetition of the small library of tracks, but it's nice to see the option retained. The music also creates the ambience of civilisation within communities, so in that sense, it's still worth having within the game.

Unfortunately, there is one very negative area in which Fallout: New Vegas has followed in the footsteps of its predecessors.  Fallout: New Vegas is still not entirely free of bugs, with graphical glitches and clipping issues still remaining. While the Fallout series has not had a reputation for faultless programming, partially a consequence of its extensive scope, it's disappointing and jarring to have an enemy – or worse, yourself – stuck in the side of a rock with no way to escape.

Nevertheless, Fallout: New Vegas certainly progresses the series, working on the framework of Fallout 3, while taking more influence from the preceding Fallout games and instituting some of the visions that were planned for Van Buren. Paradoxically, in terms of the series progression, it may have made more sense to term this to be the third instalment in the main series, and have named Fallout 3 something along the lines of Fallout: Capital Wasteland. Either way, Fallout: New Vegas is a reasonably well-crafted and frequently fun game which only suffers from the minor disappointment of persistent bugs.

reviewText: A typical day in the Mojave wasteland - I woke up in my dirty matress and took a drink form the nearby radioactive pond where I had recently shot a bunch of legionaier soilders. After getting dressed in my power armour attitre I was abducted by robots and asked to stop another robot controling more robots. After being returned to the fleshy world I decided to help liberate a village from marauders return thier livestock and kill a traitor amist them after which I was rewared with a few pieces of massive cockroach and mutated rats ♥♥♥♥. While nomming on my new found lunch, my stomach started to make strange noises, it was then I decieded to seek a docter about my unnatural levels of radiation. On my way to see the docter I stoped over in the nearest city to stock up on ammunion and repiar my equipment. Unfourtnaty the city had been taken over by bandits. After repeditive death after another, I managed to clear out the city allowing its inhabitants to atend to me and my new found partner. Finally, after hours of treking through the nuclear wasteland, I reached a docter who was willing to treat my radiation.\n\nThats just an hour worth of gameplay :P

After being returned to the fleshy world I decided to help liberate a village from marauders return thier livestock and kill a traitor amist them after which I was rewared with a few pieces of massive cockroach and mutated rats ♥♥♥♥. While nomming on my new found lunch, my stomach started to make strange noises, it was then I decieded to seek a docter about my unnatural levels of radiation. On my way to see the docter I stoped over in the nearest city to stock up on ammunion and repiar my equipment. Unfourtnaty the city had been taken over by bandits. After repeditive death after another, I managed to clear out the city allowing its inhabitants to atend to me and my new found partner. Finally, after hours of treking through the nuclear wasteland, I reached a docter who was willing to treat my radiation.\n\nThats just an hour worth of gameplay :P

reviewText:
War. War Never changes.

From the time these words are spoken, to the moment you reach the end of the game, you will experience one of the best game’s out there.

Outdated engine, loads of glitches, and too few voices for too many characters. Despite these flaws, I believe Fallout New Vegas is the best game I’ve ever played. A fantastic story, interesting and diverse characters, hundreds of mods, and a return to good ol’ Fallout.

I bought this game a few years ago, knowing only a little about Fallout, having only played Fallout 3 a few times, never for long, when I was young. So, with Fallout 3, I bought this game, not knowing what to expect. Here I am, a few years later, with over 250 hours of gameplay under my belt, and still more to come. Over the course of these years I have played every other Fallout game in existence and have learned the lore and history of both the game and it’s world. Every time I play one of the other games, I am hit by a sense of wonder, but I always end up coming back to this one, New Vegas.

New Vegas has everything you could want from a Fallout game, bringing you back to the West Coast and the world of old Fallout. Hundreds of cool guns and missions and a gigantic world to discover, not to mention some pretty good DLC, for the most part.

Las Vegas, now dubbed New Vegas, is the last bastion of civilization in the world, as far as it’s inhabitants can tell, led by the mysterious and enigmatic Mr. House. The NCR, who you may remember from Fallout 2, have spread out to Nevada to find the Hoover Dam. With the discovery of the Dam, comes the discovery of the antithesis to everything the NCR stands for, The Legion, a group founded under the ideals of old Rome. Before the start of the game, the NCR and the Legion duked it out over control of the Dam, the NCR just barely winning. Now the Legion is back, and after revenge. Mr. House sits in the protection of the walled city of New Vegas, ruling over it’s inhabitants under the ideals of the old world, as the NCR dukes it out once again with the Legion, with plans of his own. You are a Courier, a messenger of sorts, tasked with delivering a mysterious package by order of Mr. House, who must unite the Mojave Wasteland under the rule of either the Legion, the NCR, Mr. House, or yourself. And with that, the best game of the Fallout series starts.

So with my FIVE STAR RECOMMENDATION, go ahead, buy the game, and start the journey of your life.

reviewText:
I'm on the verge deciding whether I like  Fallout 3 or Fallout NV more, for me they're on the same level. I'm going to make a short comparison:

Fallout NV:
- Less power armor focused
- Strong wild-west theme (some like it some not)
- Interesting characters, questline for every companion.
- More things to do (like gambling etc.)
- An amazing faction system, way better than FO3's karma.
- Some of the best DLC's I've played in any game.

FO3:
- Real post-apocalyptic feeling.
- Simpler-cleaner game mechanics
- The main antagonists are much more strong and interesting
- Less bugs (only for me?)
- More interesting locations and landmarks
- Creepier, more eerie than FONV.

Anyway if you plan on buying the game buy the Ultimate/GOTY edition with all the dlc, it worth it. Just like with any Bethesda game, modding it is highly advised (not only to get rid of the numerous bugs, but to enhanced the gameplay and outdated visuals).

reviewText:
After admittedly rushing through Fallout 3, I felt a bit let down at its seemingly linear plot and short main questline. I already had picked up New Vegas from this past Winter Sale and had been waiting to try it out, in hopes that it would extend my simple experience of 3. What I jumped into far exceeded my expectations. I felt like I was truly the player running across the wasteland. Whereas in 3 I was a kid from the vault following a paper trail to my father to do good for Washington, D.C., here in NV I had all the power to do anything from creating an autonomous society to becoming the main driver for a loose military force.

What I learned from 3 and my initial playthrough of NV is you have to pace yourself. Explore aimlessly a lot more than you find yourself doing in the sister/rival Elder Scrolls games. There is no actual endgame in ES like there is in FO. You have to leave your mark before you make the big choices. You also find your personal morals driving your decisions. And unlike ES, the citizens of the Mojave Wasteland will not forget you. Screw the NCR, they will screw you back.

I found myself enjoying the company of the smaller tribes" more than the big players like the NCR and Caesar. Again inserting myself as the player character
date: I was another person in the wasteland
recommended: I just ended up shaping it to my whim.\n\nIf I had to criticize one thing
hoursPlayed: it is the somewhat-lack of incentive to scour every location. Reaching Level 28 on my second playthrough and choosing the Explorer perk was a good choice to find some difficult and useful locations
voteText: but just as many of them were not. I found a place called "Chance's Map" which only on further investigation did I learn it meant something
helpfulPercent: but only in the comics. I wasn't expecting valuable NPC's to be waiting every 5 meters
votesHelpful: but possibly have a bit more to find under the rock. Despite this
votesTotal: the minutia in development is another reason to praise this game.\n\nAnd the average 2010 graphics? Doesn't matter
votesFunny: it was all about the detail and story
commentsCount: anyway.\n\n9.75/10"

With much tighter writing it provides plenty of the series' trademark black humor that Fallout 1+2 fans will remember. The only downside is that it still runs on the Gamebryo engine but Obsidian really did push the engine to its limits. Unlike Fallout 3, All the DLC's for NV are tied together; Dead Money, Honest Hearts, Old World Blues and Lonesome Road, all adding unique settings and characters too each DLC. Buy the Ultimate Edition to this game and you will have hours upon hours of fun.

reviewText:
(Keep in mind that this review isn't affected by mods, which add so much to the game)

STORY:
Fallout: New Vegas is an open world RPG set in the year 2281, 200 years after a nuclear war with China devastated America, and in a post-apocalyptic version of Nevada, California, and Arizona. In Fallout: New Vegas, you play as the Courier, who is hired by a delivery service to transport a very important package across the Mojave Desert to the Las Vegas Strip. However, problems arise when your character is shot in the head and left for dead in the middle of the wasteland by a mysterious man who steals the package. After being found by a friendly robot and brought to a local doctor, the Courier goes back out into the arid wasteland to search for answers to questions such as, “Who tried to kill me?” and “What was in the package?”

When first starting out, it can be a little intimidating, as you’re thrown into this huge world without any sense of direction or objective, except to find the package you were assaulted for. From there, you have to earn the trust of people just trying to live in a cruel, unforgiving place. Once you figure out what you’re doing, you embark on your quest of vengeance.

The game really immerses you in the story, but doesn’t force it on you, so you can always have your own fun with the game. Also, this may be a little bit of a spoiler, but when you finish the story, you are told how your actions affected the future and some people you came across during your adventure. I would have to rate the story: 9/10.


MUSIC:
The game is set in a post-apocalyptic world, but before that, in-game American society was fascinated with 50’s culture, so on the game’s radio stations, music from the 40’s, 50’s, and the 60’s and artists such as Frank Sinatra and Dean Martin plays. This music really adds to the environment because all of the buildings, features, landscape of the world were the same before the event that changed everything, just destroyed, so it’s nice to see that something from the old world survive for 200+ years. Also, the game features background music for intense situations, but I never really notice it that much. I would rate the music: 9/10.


GAMEPLAY:
Fallout: New Vegas plays like a regular RPG mixed with a FPS. In the beginning, you can select your SPECIAL stats, SPECIAL meaning Strength, Perception, Endurance, Charisma, Intelligence, Agility, and Luck. Based on which category you put your points into, your main skills will be different and you’ll be better at some things, but not others. For instance, if you put a lot of points into Agility, you’ll be able to draw and reload your weapon faster and your Guns skill level and your Sneak skill level will be increased. But, to put points into Agility, there will be a category that won’t have as many points in it. There is no way to get every category maxed out at first because the system is designed to make your character have strengths and weaknesses.

Fallout: New Vegas has a combat system called V.A.T.S. You can use it to pause the battle and aim at a body part of an enemy to inflict serious damage. Doing this uses Action Points, which are used and then replenish over time, so that way you can’t use the system all the time.

The game also has a karma and reputation system which both affect how NPCs react to you. The karma system is a system that reflects all the good and evil decisions you make in the game and how those decisions are perceived in the eyes of the NPCs you meet. You can be very good, good, neutral, evil, or very evil. It all depends on your decisions throughout the game. In New Vegas, the karma system doesn’t have as big of an effect as it did in other Fallout games. Instead, the reputation system has a more important place. The reputation system is a system that tracks how the many factions in the game feel about you and your actions. If you perform actions that benefit a group, you’ll gain Fame, but if you perform actions that harm a group, you’ll gain Infamy. Your reputation with a group is measurement of the balance of Fame and Infamy. If you’re more famous with a group, they can give you discounts from vendors, allow you to get into areas you otherwise you be able to get into, etc. If you’re more infamous, you can be shot on sight. Those aren’t all the significant gameplay features, but those are the best. I’d have to give the gameplay a 9/10 for the reputation system and SPECIAL system.


GRAPHICS:
For a game that came out in 2010, the graphics aren’t all that spectacular. The ground and the walls don't have many details, but the people you encounter look fine. The weapons and armor are pretty detailed, but most are grey, boring, and not fun to look at. The outside world is a big mix of browns, but that is a good thing due to the setting being post-apocalyptic, so everything would be discolored and dreary. The sky is blue mixed with blue with white clouds, so nothing special there. I’d rate the graphics: 7.5/10.


CONTROLS:
The controls in this game are not very complicated and it’s very neat that you can change buttons around so that way you can play in your own style. For instance, the default setting for the B (Xbox 360) is to activate the Pip-Boy, but I changed that to the right bumper. Other than that, there’s nothing special to say about the controls, it’s pretty standard FPS/RPG controls. I have to rate the controls: 9/10.


There you have it, that’s my review of Fallout: New Vegas with a score of 8.7/10. The game is not perfect, but I definitely recommend it to people who haven’t checked it out and like RPGs. Thank you for reading!

reviewText:
After starting my adventures in the Wasteland with Fallout 4, and also continuing them in Fallout 3, I can easily see why most people favour New Vegas over the aforementioned two games.
The amount of quests and quest consequences is astonishing for a 2010 game, with only a 10 month development cycle. Even without any DLC at all, this game easily stands on it's own as a classic for years to come, if not already.

And that's not even the best bit about New Vegas, i'd say the most exciting thing to come when you pick up this game is the amount of Mods you'll be downloading, because oh boy, there's a ton of them.

It's amazing how a community can extend the lifecycle of one game for 6 years straight, and for more to come.
Overall, do I recommend this game?
Hell. Yes.

reviewText: Truly a unique experience, this game puts guns, a big wasteland, and a great story together to make one of the best RPG's of all time. You play as a Courier carrying a platinum chip to New Vegas only to be shot in the head and buried alve, but your not dead as you were dug up and brought back to life by a doctor in the town of Goodsprings. The Mojavi Wasteland is giant, so many things to explore, pick up, sell, shoot, and all that while listening to some good tunes from the 30s, 40s and 50s on your Pip-Boy. The last thing I would like to mention is that the characters of this game I will never forget, simply wonderfully designed and voice acted. This is a must have, Legendary game and a plus is that there is an active community so be sure to check falloutnewvegas nexus for good mods. Simply, just get this game and you will see what I mean.

reviewText:
Fallout New Vegas is a world within a game. I have spent over a hundred hours on this game, and I am still have things to do. Focusing on the conflict between the NCR and the Legion, you play as a courier, who, at first, is not part of it. After getting shot in the head, you awake in Goodsprings, in good health, and ready for revenge. Compared to Fallout 3, I personally choose New Vegas over 3. New Vegas not only lets you choose the fate of New Vegas, you also become integreted with the other faction. WIth 4 different endings to choose from, as well dozens of side quest, New Vegas will keep you playing for hours on end.


The only main complaint I have with this game is the glitches. Though amusing and funny at first, getting stuck in a wall will make you not only mad, it will at often times make you curse at your PC/laptop. Along with the wall gltich, the game might, and WILL crash on you. Whether it is causing the game to get stuck in a loop, getting a black screen, or crashing the game all entirely, the crashes are very annoying, and, at often times, forcing you to restart at you last save point or auto save. The graphics are also lack-luster, looking as if they used the same engine to make Fallout 3. Nevertheless, what this game under-preforms in graphics, New Vegas more than enough makes it up with gameplay and story.


The story is captivating, often times making you want more, and forcing you to make choices that often test whether or not you are a moral person. Will you help the noble cause of the NCR and fight to power the Mojave with over, aid the slavers of the east, Ceasar's Legion, or will you lend a hand the mysterious Mr. Robert House, the ruler of New Vegas. Gameplay is also where this game shines. Though utilizing a first person view like its predecessor 3, New Vegas stays loyal with its RPG roots, focusing more on and RPG-like gaming rather than an action packed shooter. New Vegas combat focuses on how well you make your chracter, and on what you specialize it on. Every time you level up, you gain a certain number of points to spend, and what category you spend it on determinds what you are good at.


New Vegas is a grand game. WIth hundreds of things to do, New Vegas will certainly be worth the price. The gameplay and story by far overshadows the glitches and graphics. Note that New Vegas isn't for the faint of heart, for the is much more than your typical FPS game. New Vegas will leave you breathless, and glad you purchased this game.

reviewText:
where do i start with fallout new vegas?

this game is hands down one of my favorite games ever made. Why? because you can do almost anything.

want to play this with mods? check!
want great companions? check!
choose your own path? check!
Hardcore mode? check!
want to kill a hooker? check!
kill people with a rolling pin while dressed up like a hooker? check!

Like I said, in the world of fallout almost anything is possible (literally). but they're are a few game breaking bugs that can be hilarious or just downright anger inducing. for example, veteran fallout players will remember the glitch where a body will stretch out a far distance and start spazzing out around the map, thats pretty funny. But, when you are invading gun runners to make a few caps and the gun runner protectron somehow finds a way out of the stand he is stuck in... he is literally unkillable (mini nukes just tickle him)

Aside from the few bugs and glitches this game has, fallout new vegas has character customazation, want to be a female, ok. want to be a guy with a weird hair cut and hair color? thats ok, society wont judge you at all! Next in the customazation is the attributes you can give your character. there are 7 well balanced attributes to this game and they are: strength, perception, endurance, charisma, intelligence, agility, and luck. (I normally max out my strength so i can carry more loot) and each attribute also gives a minor bonus to certain skills.

Strength increases yor melee damage, increases carry capacity, and improves aiming down sights (ADS) with all of the weapons( and how fast you can swing with melee weapons)

Perception is used to see how far away an enemy is on your radar

Endurance is pretty self explanitory, it increases your health, increases radiation resistance and poison resistance

Charisma increases your companions chance to tell you a secret about themselve and/or give a quest relating to them

Intelligence increases the amount of skill points availible when you level up

Agility increases your reload speed with weapons and the amount of action points you have availible

And last is luck, Luck increases your chance at scoring a critical hit, and also it gives you a better chance of winning at slot machines

These attributes are all really well balanced and most can be used sometimes in a conversation to persuade or give information

Fallout New Vegas has many factions for you to side with end, there is Caesars Legion, the NCR, Mr. House, or, yourself. along with these major factions there are minor factions like The Followers of the Apocolypse, Goodsprings, The Great Khans, and more.

One thing I really enjoyed about Fallout New Vegas was the hardcore mode. in hardcore you would have to eat, sleep, and drink. along with ammo actually weighing you down, stimpacks heal over time( so no endlessly shoving stimpacks down your throat to survive a deathclaw encounter) and you need a doctors bag, or doctor to heal a crippled limb.(side note by the time it takes you to get to the first tier of sleep, eating, and drinking deprivation you could be a quarter through the game, and yes there is a mod that was released by one of the developers to help make this a bit more... well, Hardcore)

So in short, I really recommend that people that dont have this game to pick it up right now, it is well worth the money( and time) to play this game. but be warned, once you play this game, it will eat your time like a fat kid in a cookie store.

reviewText:
One of the best Fallout games there is (until Fallout 4)

Set in the Mojave, the game really does take the game back to its western roots with the original factions involved (Mainly the NCR, which is now a superpower of sorts).

Though not made by the same team that made Fallout 3, not only does it have the same mechanics (with a few extra ones added such as 'Hardcore mode'.) it really does offer more. For example, there are more requests, perks, weapons in it as well as the ability to customize your weapons.

The quests (including DLCs) are much better, in my opinion. In Fallout 3 there is really only 3 different endings but they are more or less the same. The DLCs weren't bad but it did feel repeative and more of a shooter than RGP. In NV, it offers different quest lines for different factions in the story thus giving us a  greater depth to the story and it really does feel like your actions do determin the outcome of the Mojave.

The only problems I find with this game is, that is sometimes crashes and gives my PC the Blue screen of death every hour and then. Most of the glitches are patched but it can become a pest. Also, Cazadores are complete c*nts. No matter what level you are, or what weapon you have, they always seem to wipe you out without a problem. And they always come in swarms which becomes impossible to fight unless you have Mini nuke to Shoah the scum.

Overall, 9/10 game. Must get!
